questions.text: An intern was asked to observe a histological section of the esophagus. What type of cells are seen by him in the basal layer of the epithelium of the esophagus?
questions.solution:
The lining epithelium of the esophagus is the stratified squamous epithelium. The basal layer of cells present in the stratified squamous epithelium is composed of columnar cells.

The stratified squamous epithelium is made up of several layers of cells:

  • The cells in the deepest/basal layer of the epithelium are columnar
  • The cells in the middle layers are polygonal
  • The cells in the superficial layers are flattened squamous cells

Related Pearl: Various Types of Epithelium, Their Location and Functions

questions.text: The type of joint marked in the image below is _________:
questions.solution:
The joint marked in the above image is the costotransverse joint, which is a synovial type of joint.

The various types of joints in the thoracic wall include:

Type of Joint  Examples 
Synovial joint

Costovertebral joint

Costotranverse joint

Interchondral joints
Primary cartilaginous joint/Synchondrosis Costochondral joint
Secondary cartilaginous/Symphyses joint Manubriosternal and xiphisternal joints

Sternocostal joints: These are the joints between the costal cartilages of the first seven ribs and the sternum.

  • The joint between the 1st costal cartilage and manubrium is a fibrocartilaginous joint (synarthrosis).
  • The joints between the 2nd to 7th costal cartilages and the sternum are synovial joints.

The interchondral joint between the costal cartilages of the 9th and 10th ribs is never synovial and is usually absent.

Related Pearl: Articulations of ribs

  • Costotransverse: Rib to the transverse process of vertebra
  • Costochondral: Rib to the costal cartilage

Ribs 2 to 9: 3 articulations

  • Head of the rib to the inferior costal facet of the vertebral body above
  • Head of the rib to the superior costal facet of the corresponding vertebral body
  • Tubercle of the rib to the transverse process of the corresponding vertebra

Ribs 1 and 10: 2 articulations

  • Head of the rib to the corresponding vertebral body
  • Tubercle of the rib to the transverse process of the corresponding vertebra

Ribs 11 and 12: 1 articulation

  • Head of the rib to the corresponding vertebral body

Articulations with the sternum

Ribs 1- 7: True ribs - Articulate directly with a single costal cartilages 

Ribs 8-10: False ribs - Articulate with a common costal cartilage.

Ribs 11 and 12: Floating ribs - Do not articulate with the sternum

questions.text: The spinal cord in an adult terminates at which level of vertebra?
questions.solution:
Spinal cord in a adult terminates at lower border of L1.

questions.solution:
Porto-systemic shunt is not seen in the spleen.

questions.text: All of the following muscles of the tongue are supplied by the hypoglossal nerve except?
questions.solution:
Palatoglossus is not supplied by the hypoglossal nerve.

All intrinsic and extrinsic muscles of the tongue are derived from occipital myotomes (hence innervated by the hypoglossal nerve), except palatoglossus, which is derived from the pharyngeal arch and is supplied by the vago-accessory nerve.

Note:

  • All the muscles of the tongue except palatoglossus (cranial accessory nerve through pharyngeal plexus) are supplied by hypoglossal nerve.
  • All the muscles of pharynx except stylopharyngeus (glossopharyngeal nerve) are supplied by pharyngeal plexus.
  • All muscles of soft palate except tensor veli palatini (nerve to medial pterygoid from mandibular nerve) are supplied by pharyngeal plexus.
  • All muscles of the larynx except the cricothyroid (external laryngeal nerve) are supplied by the recurrent laryngeal nerve.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male was brought to the hospital after he suffered a stab wound. CT scan revealed an injury to the part of the artery that lies lateral to pectoralis minor muscle. Which of the following vessels is least likely to have its flow cut off completely?
questions.solution:
The third part of the axillary artery lies lateral to the pectoralis minor muscle. Injury in this part causes decreased blood supply in all branches of the third part of the axillary artery. The superior thoracic artery is a branch of the first part of the axillary artery, and is, therefore, the least likely to be affected.

The axillary artery is the continuation of the subclavian artery. It extends from the outer border of 1st rib to the lower border of Teres Major.

Pectoralis Minor divides the artery into 3 parts (proximal to, posterior to, and lateral/distal to the muscle).

Part of the artery Relation to Pectoralis minor Branches
1st part Lies proximally Superior thoracic artery 
2nd part Lies posteriorly

Thoracoacromial artery

lateral thoracic artery
3rd part Lies laterally/distally

Subscapular artery

Anterior circumflex humeral artery

Posterior circumflex humeral artery

questions.text: In Zenker's diverticulum, Killian's dehiscence is a potential space in the _____ muscle.
questions.solution:
In Zenker's diverticulum. It protrudes through the Killian's dehiscence, a potential space present in the inferior constrictor muscle.

The inferior constrictor muscle is made up of 2 parts: The upper thyropharyngeus and the lower cricopharyngeus. The cricopharyngeus muscle is divisible into the superficial oblique component (pars oblique) and the deeper transverse component (pars fundiformis). These 2 components of the muscle have a potential space between them termed Killian's dehiscence.  

As a result of the uncoordinated contraction between the cricopharyngeus and upper oesophagal sphincter, mucosal herniation through the Killian's dehiscence gives rise to Zenker's diverticulum. This diverticulum is a common site for food impaction and accumulation (halitosis, regurgitation) and may cause dysphagia in affected patients. 

Note - Another potential site of diverticulum formation is the Laimer's triangle, situated below the cricopharyngeus and above the longitudinal fibres of the oesophagus. 

Related Pearl: Zenker’s Diverticulum

  • Hypopharyngeal diverticulum
  • False diverticulum
  • Pulsion diverticulum
  • Acquired diverticulum, seen in the elderly (>60 years)
  • Herniation is through the Killian’s triangle (a weak area between two parts of the inferior constrictor) in the posterior pharyngeal wall
  • Clinical features:
    • Dysphagia
    • Regurgitation
    • Halitosis
    • Aspiration
    • Gurgling sound during swallowing
  • Investigation of choice: Barium swallow (Lateral X rays)
  • Treatment
    • Cricopharyngeal myotomy
    • Surgical diverticulectomy
    • Marsupialization
    • Dohlman’s procedure

Zenker’s diverticulum

questions.text:
What is the sequence of layers that you will come across while during a paracentesis using a flank approach?
1-Transversus abdominis
2-Transversalis fascia
3- Oblique muscles
4- Campers and Scarpa fascia
questions.solution:
The correct sequence according to the question would be: Campers and Scarpa fascia - Oblique muscles - Transversus abdominis - Transversalis fascia (4-3-1-2).

Layers of the abdomen if pierced in the flanks (notice there are muscles here):

  • Skin
  • Superficial fascia (Campers and Scarpa)
  • External oblique
  • Internal oblique
  • Transversus abdominis
  • Transversalis fascia
  • Extraperitoneal fat
  • Parietal peritoneum

 

Layers of the abdomen if pierced in the midline approach (from superficial to deep):

  • Skin
  • Superficial fascia (Campers and Scarpa)
  • Linea alba
  • Transversalis fascia
  • Extraperitoneal fat
  • Parietal peritoneum

There are no muscles pierced in the midline approach.

questions.text: Two patients who underwent neck surgery present to you with winging of the scapula. On examination, the scapula in patient A is displaced downwards and away from the spine while in patient B, it is pulled upwards and towards the spine. Which of the following statements correctly describe the nerves injured in both of them?

choices.text: Patient A -Thoracodorsal nerve and Patient B- long thoracic nerve
Patient A - Accessory nerve and Patient B- long thoracic nerve
Both patient A and B - Long thoracic nerve
Both patient A and B - Thoracodorsal nerve

questions.solution:
Winging of scapula in Patient A is caused by paralysis of trapezius muscle that results from damage to the spinal accessory nerve (CN XI).

Winging of scapula in Patient B is caused by paralysis of serratus anterior muscle that results from damage to the long thoracic nerve, which arises from the roots of the brachial plexus (C5-C7).

Note:

Scapular winging is almost always caused by damage to one of three nerves that control muscles in your arms, back, and neck:

  • The long thoracic nerve, which controls the serratus anterior muscle
  • The dorsal scapular nerve, which controls the rhomboid muscles
  • The spinal accessory nerve, which controls the trapezius muscle

questions.text: Which of the following is not used for the identification of the facial nerve trunk?
questions.solution:
The inferior belly of the omohyoid muscle is not used as an anatomical landmark for the identification of the facial nerve trunk.

There are two methods for localization of the facial nerve trunk: 

1. Anterograde method: The facial nerve trunk is identified based on the anatomical landmarks after it exits from the stylomastoid foramen. This includes:

  • Tragal pointer/Conley's pointer - It is the inferior portion of the cartilaginous canal. The facial nerve trunk lies 1 cm deep and inferior to its tip.
  • Posterior belly of digastric - The facial nerve lies superior to the upper border of the muscle.
  • Squamotympanic fissure - It is a fissure in the temporal bone, which runs from TMJ to the tympanic cavity. The facial nerve runs through this fissure.
  • Styloid process - The facial nerve lies superficial to it.
  • Mastoid process - Upon drilling it, the nerve is identified proximally.

2. Retrograde method: The main branches of the facial nerve trunk are identified and are then traced proximally until the main tunk is identified. Some branches used for tracing the facial nerve trunk include:

  • Buccal branch - It lies in relation to the parotid gland.
  • Marginal mandibular branch - It lies in relation to the facial vessels.

questions.text: A cadaveric specimen of the circle of Willis is given below. Which of the following marked structures represents the superior cerebellar artery?
questions.solution:
The given cadaveric image is of the vascular structures(Circle of Willis) at the base of the brain. The structure marked as 'A' can be identified as the superior cerebellar artery as it is arising from the distal portion of the basilar artery, immediately before the formation of the posterior cerebral arteries(marked as B).

The superior cerebellar artery supplies the pons, pineal body, superior medullary velum and tela choroidea of the third ventricle.

Circle of Willis or circulus arteriosus: Large arterial anastomosis that unites the internal carotid and vertebrobasilar systems. It lies in the subarachnoid space within the basal cisterns that surround the optic chiasma and infundibulum.

The anterior cerebral arteries are derived from the internal carotid arteries and are linked by a small anterior communicating artery.

Posteriorly, the two posterior cerebral arteries are formed by the division of the basilar artery. They are joined to the ipsilateral internal carotid artery by a posterior communicating artery.

Related Pearl: Circle of Willis

questions.text: The suprascapular nerve is the content of which of the following triangles marked in the neck region?
questions.solution:
The suprascapular nerve (C5, C6) arises from the upper trunk of the brachial plexus. The nerve is a component of the subclavian triangle.

In the given image:

  • A – Carotid triangle
  • B – Occipital triangle 
  • C – Subclavian triangle
  • D – Muscular triangle

Contents of the subclavian triangle are:

  • 3rd part of Subclavian Artery and vein
  • Suprascapular artery and vein, transverse cervical artery
  • Supraclavicular lymph node
  • Trunks of Brachial plexus
  • Nerve to Serratus anterior
  • Branches from upper trunk – N to Subclavius, Suprascapular nerve

Related Pearl: Triangles of the Neck

questions.solution:

The deep peroneal nerve is the nerve of the anterior compartment of the leg and the dorsum of the foot. It is one of the two terminal branches of the common peroneal nerve arising between the neck of the fibula and peroneus longus. The 2nd metatarsophalangeal joint is supplied by the medial plantar nerve.

questions.text: Which of the following is responsible for the bradycardia seen in Cushing reflex?
questions.solution:
The bradycardia seen in the Cushing reflex is caused by baroreceptor activation in response to a raised arterial blood pressure.

The Cushing reflex is a triad of raised arterial blood pressure, bradycardia, and irregular respiration caused by raised intracranial pressure (ICP). Raised ICP compromises blood flow to the brain and activates the rostral ventrolateral medulla with an increase in arterial blood pressure. The increased arterial pressure maintains cerebral perfusion and activates the baroreceptor reflex that causes bradycardia.

The irregular respiration seen in the Cushing reflex is caused by inadequate blood flow and increased pressure on the brainstem.

Bainbridge reflex: It refers to the increase in the heart rate when the atrium is stretched. Whenever there is a stretch of the atrium, the stretch receptors are activated. They transmit their afferent signals through the vagus nerves to the medulla of the brain. Efferent signals are then transmitted back through vagal and sympathetic nerves to increase the heart rate and strength of heart contraction. This reflex prevents the accumulation of blood in the atria, veins, and pulmonary circulation.

J reflex: C fiber-endings close to the pulmonary vessels are called J (juxtacapillary) receptors. These receptors are stimulated by hyperinflation of the lungs or intravenous administration of capsaicin. The reflex produced is apnea followed by rapid breathing, bradycardia, and hypotension. 

Bezold Jarisch reflex (Coronary chemoreflex): Activation of chemosensitive vagal C fibers in the cardiopulmonary region (eg, juxtacapillary region of alveoli, ventricles, atria, great veins, and pulmonary artery) causes profound bradycardia, hypotension, and a brief period of apnea followed by rapid shallow breathing. This is called the Bezold Jarisch reflex and can be elicited by capsaicin, serotonin, phenylbiguanide, and veratridine. It can also be activated during myocardial infarction and on exposure to radioactive dyes during coronary angiography.

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding excitation-contraction coupling in smooth muscle?

choices.text: Sustained contraction occurs with high calcium concentration
Phosphorylation of actin is required for contraction
Cellular calcium concentration is essential to cause contraction

questions.solution:
Increased cytosolic Ca2+ is essential for contraction of smooth muscles.

Events in Excitation Contraction Coupling in Smooth Muscles.

A unitary smooth muscle is unique in that it can contract when stretched even in the absence of any extrinsic innervation. Stretch is followed by a decrease in membrane potential and an increase in the tone of the muscle.

 

Other options:

Option a: Troponin is absent in smooth muscle.

Option b: Sustained contraction of the smooth muscle occurs even when the calcium concentration falls. This is mainly because of the latch-bridge mechanism where the myosin cross-bridges remain attached to the actin. This mechanism allows for maintaining the contraction with less expenditure of energy and is particularly important in the vascular smooth muscle.

Option c: Unlike skeletal muscle where troponin binding is essential for contraction, the smooth muscle contraction requires phosphorylation of myosin (not actin).

questions.text: Which region of the cerebellum is affected when a patient exhibits an unsteady "drunk like " gait and swaying?
questions.solution:
Flocculonodular Lobe is involved in the unsteady "drunk like" gait.

Cerebellum has three parts based on function.

  • Vestibulocerebellum (or flocculonodular lobe): The oldest part of the cerebellum, has vestibular connections, and is concerned with equilibrium and gait.  
  • Spinocerebellum: The region that receives proprioceptive input from the body as well as a copy of the “motor plan” from the motor cortex. By comparing the plan with performance, it smooths and coordinates movements that are ongoing. 
  • Cerebrocerebellum: They are the newest from a phylogenetic point of view, reaching their greatest development in humans. They interact with the motor cortex in planning and programming movements.

Related Pearl: Functional Divisions of Cerebellum

Functionally, the cerebellum is divided into three parts:

Part Vestibulocerebellum/ Archicerebellum (flocculonodular lobe) - oldest part phylogenetically Spinocerebellum/ Paleocerebellum Cerebrocerebellum/ Neocerebellum - newest part phylogenetically
Constituents Nodule of vermis and flocculus Rest of the vermis and medial portions of cerebellar hemispheres Lateral portions of cerebellar hemispheres
Input Vestibular, visual and somatosensory input from the neck Proprioceptive input from dorsal columns of the spinal cord, trigeminal nerve, visual and auditory systems Cerebral cortex
Output To vestibular nuclei of the brainstem via the fastigial nucleus

Vermis - to the brainstem vis fastigial nucleus

Lateral portions - to the brainstem via the nucleus interpositus ( globose + emboliform nuclei)

 To ventrolateral nucleus of the thalamus via the dentate nucleus
Function Maintenance of equilibrium and eye movements

Smoothens and coordinates movements

Vermis - axial and proximal limb movements

Lateral regions - distal limb movements

 Planning and programming movements

questions.text: According to myogenic hypothesis of renal autoregulation the afferent arterioles contract in response to stretch-induced by______
questions.solution:
The afferent arterioles contract in response to stretch-induced by opening of calcium channels. The mechanism is called Myogenic autoregulation of renal blood flow and GFR. 

Stretch of the vascular wall allows increased movement of calcium ions from the extracellular fluid into the cells, causing them to contract. This contraction prevents excessive stretch of the vessel. This prevents excessive increase of renal blood flow and GFR by raising vascular resistance.

This mechanism may be more important in protecting the kidney from hypertension-induced injury.

Autoregulation has two main mechanisms:

  • Metabolic mechanism: Tissues produce vasodilatory metabolites that regulate flow e.g., adenosine, prostaglandins, NO, CO2, H+ and K+
  • Myogenic mechanism

questions.text: All of the following are reabsorbed in the PCT except _____________
questions.solution:
H+ is secreted in the proximal convoluted tubule and helps in the reabsorption of bicarbonate ions.

Reabsorption and secretion in different parts of the nephron:

  • Proximal convoluted tubule (PCT):
    • Sodium, water, and chloride are mainly reabsorbed here along with glucose, amino acids, and other solutes. The total solute concentration, or osmolarity, remains more or less the same all along the proximal tubule due to the high permeability to water.
    • Bile salts, oxalate, urate, and catecholamines are secreted into the PCT. 
  • Loop of Henle:
    • Thin descending limb is permeable to water, urea, and sodium. The tubular fluid becomes hypertonic.
    • Thick ascending limb: reabsorbs Na+, K+, and Cl- in the thick ascending limb, mainly by a 1-sodium, 2-chloride, 1-potassium co-transporter. Other ions like Ca+2, HCO3-, and Mg+2 are also reabsorbed here. A sodium-hydrogen counter-transporter mediates sodium reabsorption and hydrogen secretion. It is virtually impermeable to water. Since some of the solutes are reabsorbed and water is not reabsorbed, it dilutes the tubular fluid.
  • Distal convoluted tubule: Sodium, potassium, and chloride, are reabsorbed here but it is impermeable to water and urea. Therefore, even this segment dilutes the tubular fluid. This site contains sodium chloride co-transporter.
  • Late distal tubule and cortical collecting tubule:
    • Principal cells reabsorb Na and secrete K into the lumen
    • Type A intercalated cells reabsorb K and secrete H into the lumen
    • Type B intercalated cells reabsorb H and secrete HCO3 in alkalosis
    • Late distal and cortical collecting tubules are impermeable to urea, reabsorb Na in response to aldosterone and water in response to ADH or vasopressin. Therefore, the degree of urine formation depends upon the action of ADH on these tubules.
  • Medullary collecting duct: 
    • Reabsorption of water under ADH influence
    • Reabsorption of urea
    • Secretion of Hydrogen ions.

Other options:

Urea is passively reabsorbed with water in the PCT.

Phosphate is reabsorbed in the PCT via secondary active transport through sodium-phosphate symporters.

Urate is both reabsorbed and secreted in the PCT.

questions.text: Functional residual capacity is:

choices.text: Volume that remains after forced expiration

questions.solution:
Functional Residual Capacity (FRC) is expiratory reserve volume + residual volume.

From the picture given below, (FRC = ERV + RV).

Lung Capacities:

The total lung capacity can be broken down into alternative capacities that help to define functioning lungs.

  • The vital lung capacity refers to the maximum amount of air expired from the fully inflated lung or maximum inspiratory level.
  • The inspiratory capacity is the maximum amount of air inspired from the end-expiratory level.
  • The functional residual capacity represents the volume of the air remaining in the lungs after expiration of a normal breath.

Lung volumes, capacities, and their combinations are being tested year after year in the various competitive exams.

questions.text: A stroke in the medulla and pons with complete obliteration of the vagal input to the oesophagus is likely to cause?

choices.text: Elimination of primary oesophageal peristalsis only
Elimination of secondary oesophageal peristalsis only
Elimination of both primary and secondary oesophageal peristalsis
No change in  primary and secondary oesophageal peristalsis

questions.solution:
Absence of vagal input to the oesophagus will result in the elimination of only the primary peristalsis of oesophagus. The secondary peristalsis will remain intact due to the activity of intrinsic myenteric nerve plexus.

Oesophagal peristalsis: There are two types of oesophageal peristaltic movements: primary and secondary.

A. Primary peristalsis:

  • It occurs as a continuation of the peristaltic wave that begins in the pharynx and spreads into the oesophagus during the pharyngeal stage of swallowing.
  • It passes from the pharynx to oesophagus, within about 8 to 10 seconds.
  • However, due to the effect of gravity in an upright position, the food passes within 5 to 8 seconds.

B. Secondary peristalsis:

  • It occurs if the primary peristaltic wave failed to empty the food from the oesophagus into the stomach.
  • Secondary peristalsis is initiated by the distension of the oesophagal wall by the retained food.
  • Waves continue until all the food is emptied into the stomach.
  • Secondary peristaltic waves are initiated partly by intrinsic neural circuits in the myenteric nervous system and partly by reflexes that begin in the pharynx.
  • Pharyngeal reflexes are then transmitted upward through vagal afferent fibres to the medulla and back again to the oesophagus through glossopharyngeal and vagal efferent nerve fibres.

 Control of peristaltic waves:

  • The musculature of the pharyngeal wall and upper third of the oesophagus is striated muscle. These regions are controlled by skeletal nerve impulses from the glossopharyngeal and vagus nerves.
  • The musculature of the lower two-thirds of the oesophagus is smooth muscle. This region is strongly controlled by the vagus nerves, which act through connections with the oesophagal myenteric nervous system.

 Effect of obliteration of vagal input to the oesophagus:

  • When the vagal nerves are cut, or the vagal input is obliterated by any other cause such as stroke, the primary peristalsis, solely dependent on the vagal innervation, is eliminated.
  • However, the intrinsic myenteric nerve plexus of the oesophagus becomes excitable, with a few days, which causes strong secondary peristaltic waves.
  • Therefore, even after paralysis of the brain stem swallowing reflex, food fed by a tube into the oesophagus passes into the stomach due to the secondary peristaltic movements.

questions.text: A 50-year-old female complains of chronic low backache with neurological signs. An MRI reveals a lesion involving the left side of the T11 - T12 spinal cord parenchyma which is just compressing the left side of the cord. Which of the following sensory/motor deficit can be expected on the right side, below the level of the lesion?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario, with a lesion in the left side of the spinal cord, can be compared to that of Brown-sequard syndrome. Hence, the female would have a loss of temperature sensation on the right side of the body below the level of the lesion

Brown-sequard syndrome:

Caused due to hemisection of the Spinal cord. It can also be caused by fracture-dislocation of the vertebral column, by a bullet or stab wound, or by an expanding tumor.

Clinical features:

  • Pyramidal tract: Pyramidal weakness (ipsilateral upper motor neuron type of paralysis) below the level of the lesion on the same side as the lesion (pyramidal tract crosses in the medulla).
  • Dorsal columns: Impaired fine touch, 2 point discrimination, proprioception, vibration below the level of the lesion on the same side of the lesion (dorsal column fibers cross in the medulla).
  • Spinothalamic tract: Loss of pain, temperature, crude touch, pressure sensation below the level of the lesion on the contralateral side of the lesion (spinothalamic tract crosses midline after entering the cord).

Related Pearl: Brown Sequard syndrome (Hemisection of spinal cord)

Related Pearl: Tracts of spinal cord

questions.text: A researcher is studying the phases of the ventricular muscle action potential as shown below. Which phase represents the closing of fast sodium channels?
questions.solution:
Phase 1 represents the closure of fast sodium channels.

Phases of cardiac muscle action potential.

  • Phase 0 (Depolarization): Opening of fast sodium channels. When the cardiac cell is stimulated, the fast sodium channels(voltage-gated sodium channels) open and causes sodium influx. This depolarizes the cell and the membrane potential becomes positive. It reached about +20 mV and the sodium channels close. 
  • Phase 1 (Initial repolarization): Closing of fast sodium channels. The fast sodium channel close and the potassium channels open. the potassium ions leave the cell leading to repolarisation. 
  • Phase 2 (Plateau): Fast potassium channels close and calcium channels open. The slowly opening voltage gated Ca2+ channels start opening in phase 0 and 1. The influx of calcium through these channels is balanced by the a decrease in efflux of potassium via the potassium channels. This produces the plateau. 
  • Phase 3 (Rapid repolarization): Slow potassium channels open and calcium channels close. The potassium ions leave the cell through slow potassium channels and the calcium channels close stopping the influx of calcium ions. This ends the plateau and brings the membrane potential to resting level. 
  • Phase 4 (Resting membrane potential):  around −80 to −90 millivolts.

questions.text: Glucose is absorbed in intestine by?
questions.solution:
Glucose is absorbed in the intestine by secondary active transport (sodium co-transport).

The energy for glucose transport is provided indirectly, by the active transport of Na+ out of the cell. This maintains the concen­tration gradient across the luminal border of the cell so that more Na+ and consequently more glucose enter.

Though both secondary active transport and facilitated diffusion play a role in glucose absorption, it is the initial active transport of sodium through the basolateral membranes of the intestinal epithelial cells that provide the eventual force for moving glucose through the membranes as well. So, secondary active transport is the single best answer for this question.

questions.text: A physiologist is studying the structure of a skeletal muscle sarcomere. He takes a cross-section of sarcomere at a level that appears dark as shown in the below image. What will he find?
questions.solution:
The image shows a sarcomere which is the area between two dark Z-lines. The arrow marks the dark band (A band) and consists of thick filaments (myosin) surrounded by 6 thin filaments (actin, tropomyosin, troponin)

The difference in refractive index of various muscle fibres, give the appearance of cross-striations when viewed under a microscope. In the figure, note the section through various levels and the myofilaments observed.

  • Section through I band → only actin (thin filament)
  • Section through A band (Excluding H zone) → Actin and Myosin
  • Section through H zone → only myosin (thick filament). 
  • Section through M line → thick filament linked with accessory proteins. Pseudo-H zone is referred to the lighter areas around the M-line including the M-line.
  • The section at AI junction → both actin and myosin

Related Pearl: Microanatomy of Muscle Fibres

  • Each muscle consists of numerous muscle fibres.
  • Each skeletal muscle fibre is multi nucleated, bonded by sarcolemma, enclosing sarcoplasm, smooth muscle and cardiac muscles are uninucleated. 
  • Within the sarcoplasm, there are several hundreds of nuclei arranged in the periphery just beneath the sarcolemma.
  • The sarcoplasm also consists of evenly distributed, longitudinal threads called myofibrils.
  • Each myofibril consists of thick (myosin) and thin (actin) filaments overlapping each other.
  • The portion of myofibril which consists of thick filaments is known as A band or dark band, and the portion of a myofibril between two A bands consisting of only thin filaments is known I band or Light band.
  • Thus the A band consists of both thick and thin filaments, where as I band consists of only thin filaments.
  • In the middle of ‘A’ band, there are only thick filaments with no overlapping thin filaments. This zone is known as ‘H’ zone. In the middle of H zone, there is a dark band known as ‘M’ band.
  • In the middle of I band, there is a dark ‘Z’ disc or Krause's membrane.
  • The segment of the myofibril between two Z discs is known as the sarcomere.

questions.text: In the following LV pressure-volume loop diagram, the mitral valve will close at point ______
questions.solution:
The mitral valve will close at point B.

The volume-pressure curve represents the changes in volume and pressure in the left ventricle during a single cardiac cycle. The relationship between ventricular pressure (Y-axis) and volume (X-axis) throughout the cardiac cycle is represented by this loop.

  • A - Mitral valve opens
  • B - Mitral valve closes
  • C - Aortic valve opens
  • D - Aortic valve closes

Phase I: Period of filling

It begins at a ventricular volume of about 50 ml (end-systolic volume) and a diastolic pressure of 2 to 3 mm Hg. As venous blood flows into the ventricle from the left atrium, the ventricular volume normally increases to about 120 ml, called the end-diastolic volume and the diastolic pressure rising to about 5 to 7 mm Hg.

Phase II: Period of isovolumic contraction

During isovolumic contraction, the volume of the ventricle does not change because all valves are closed. However, the pressure inside the ventricle increases to equal the pressure in the aorta (80 mm Hg) as depicted by point C.

Phase III: Period of ejection

During ejection, the systolic pressure rises even higher because of still more contraction of the ventricle. At the same time, the volume of the ventricle decreases because the aortic valve has now opened and blood flows out of the ventricle into the aorta.

Phase IV: Period of isovolumic relaxation

At the end of the period of ejection (point D), the aortic valve closes and the ventricular pressure falls back to the diastolic pressure level. The line labeled “IV” traces this decrease in intraventricular pressure without any change in volume. Thus, the ventricle returns to its starting point, with about 50 ml of blood left in the ventricle and at an atrial pressure of 2 to 3 mm Hg.

The area subtended by this functional volume-pressure diagram (the shaded area, labeled “EW”) represents the net external work output of the ventricle during its contraction cycle.

questions.text: The image shows the oxygen-haemoglobin dissociation curve plotted during different conditions. Which among the following conditions would result in curve D?
questions.solution:
The oxygen hemoglobin curve denoted by the curve D will be observed during Acidosis.

Conditions that cause a right shift (C->D) in the oxygen hemoglobin curve are: (Conditions with the increased requirement of O2 - metabolically active tissues)

  • Hypoxia and Hypercarbia - Metabolically active tissues utilize O2 and tissues produce CO2
  • ↓ pH (Acidosis)- Secondary to increased CO2 production.
  • ↑ in temperature, heat
  • ↑ in 2,3-DPG - increased anaerobic glycolysis

Conditions that cause a left shift (B <-C)  in the oxygen hemoglobin dissociation curve are:

  • Decreased carbon dioxide (hypocarbia) (Option B)
  • ↑ pH of the blood
  • ↓ in the temperature of the body (hypothermia) (Option A)
  • ↓ in 2,3-DPG (Option C)
  • Fetal hemoglobin

Curve A represents the Myoglobin-O2 binding curve. It is a rectangular hyperbola (unlike a sigmoid curve of Oxy-hemoglobin curve). This is because it only has a single oxygen binding site. It is present in muscle in large amounts and can provide oxygen to muscles even at low blood oxygen levels.

Related Pearl: Factors affecting 2,3 -DPG

  • Chronic hypoxia
  • Anemia
  • Accilimitization (high altitude)
  • Thyroid hormone
  • Growth hormone
  • Androgens
  • Exercise
  • Stored blood
  • Acidosis

questions.text: C wave of JVP represents:

choices.text: Tricuspid bulge into right atrium during isovolumetric ventricular contraction
Tricuspid bulge into right atrium during isovolumetric ventricular relaxation

questions.solution:
'C' wave in JVP represents tricuspid bulge into right atrium during isovolumetric ventricular contraction.

Characteristics of JVP :

  • a wave corresponds to atrial systole which causes regurgitation of some blood into the great veins.
  • c wave occurs due to the increase in atrial pressure caused by bulging of the tricuspid valve into the right atrium during isovolumetric ventricular contraction.
  • x descent occurs due to the fall in atrial pressure during ventricular systole due to pulling of valve leaflets.
  • v wave is seen at the end of ventricular contraction and occurs due to the slow venous filling which causes an increase in atrial pressure.
  • y descent occurs due to the passive emptying of the right atrium into the right ventricle.

Related Pearl: JVP waveform and the abnormalities

1) The a-wave corresponds to atrial contraction.

Abnormality Conditions
Prominent a-waves Pulmonary hypertension, right atrial thrombus/ mass, and tricuspid stenosis
Cannon a-waves

Complete AV block, ventricular tachycardia, and premature atrial/ junctional/ ventricular beats
Absent a-waves Atrial fibrillation

 

2) The c-wave corresponds to the bulging of tricuspid valve into right atrium during ventricular contraction.

 

3) The x-descent corresponds to atrial relaxation during atrial diastole.

Abnormality Conditions
Absent x-descent Severe tricuspid regurgitation
Rapid x-descent Cardiac tamponade

 

4) The v-wave corresponds to the venous filling of right atrium.

Abnormality Conditions
Dominant v-waves Tricuspid regurgitation

 

5) The y-descent corresponds to the passive emptying of the right atrium into right ventricle.

Abnormality Conditions
Prolonged y-descent Tricuspid stenosis
Rapid y-descent

Constrictive pericarditis and isolated severe tricuspid regurgitation
Absent y-descent Cardiac tamponade

questions.text: The enzyme that does not require copper for its functioning is:
questions.solution:
Glutathione peroxidase requires selenium in the form of selenocysteine and not copper.

Selenium:

Selenium is an important trace element that is a part of the 21st amino acid Selenocysteine.

There are many selenium-containing enzymes such as :

  • Glutathione peroxidase
  • De-iodinase
  • Thioredoxin reductase

Selenium is also an intracellular antioxidant that complements the role of Vitamin E. Dietary sources of selenium include seafood, muscle meat, and some cereals.

Copper:

Copper is a part of numerous enzymes like amine oxidases, ferroxidase (ceruloplasmin), cytochrome c oxidase, superoxide dismutase, tyrosinase (melanin synthesis), lysyl oxidase (cross-linking in collagen), and dopamine hydroxylase. It is also a component of ferroportin, which is involved in iron absorption.

Copper deficiency disorders:

1. Wilson’s disease: It is an autosomal recessive disorder, due to ATP7 B mutation, a gene encoding for copper transporting ATPase in the cells. There is defective biliary copper excretion from liver cells, leading to copper deposits in the liver and brain.

2. Menke’s (Kinky or Steely) hair syndrome: It is an X linked recessive condition, where there is a mutation in the ATP7A gene. There is defective copper-binding P-type ATPase and copper is not mobilized from the intestine.

3. MEDNIK syndrome: A rare multisystem disorder of copper metabolism with features of both Wilson’s and Menke’s disease.

questions.text: An 8-year-old girl presented to OPD  with multiple pigmented papular lesions on her face, neck, and forearm and corneal injection following exposure to the sun. Which DNA repair mechanism is defective in this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical picture and the history is suggestive of Xeroderma pigmentosum. The DNA repair mechanism that is defective in this condition is  Nucleotide Excision Repair (NER).

Xeroderma Pigmentosum (XP) is a rare autosomal recessive genetic disorder characterized by defective DNA repair which leads to clinical and cellular hypersensitivity to ultraviolet radiation and other carcinogenic agents.

The given image shows hyperkeratotic lesions with some induration suspicious of actinic keratosis and early squamous cell carcinoma. Also numerous hyper-pigmented lentigos and xerosis on the entire front of the face.

questions.text: Which of the following glucose transporters would facilitate the uptake of glucose by the skeletal muscles which are mediated by insulin?
questions.solution:
The glucose transporter that is responsible for insulin-stimulated uptake of the glucose by the skeletal muscles is GLUT-4.

Normally, a pool of GLUT-4 molecules is maintained within vesicles in the cytoplasm of the insulin-sensitive cells. When the insulin receptors in them are stimulated, the vesicles move rapidly and fuse themselves to the cell membrane and facilitate the transport of glucose molecules into the cells.

This GLUT-4 receptor is also present in cardiac muscle and adispose tissues.

questions.text: Which metalloprotein is responsible for the metabolism of artificial flovours and additives ?
questions.solution:
Cytochrome P450 is involved in the metabolism of flavour/colour additives which are examples of xenobiotics.

Hydroxylation of xenobiotics is done by Cytochrome P450.The members of the cytochrome P450 family generate Fe = O3+. This is a powerful oxidant that participates in the reduction and neutralization of a broad range of xenobiotics via the two-electron reduction of O2.

Cytochrome p450 is a heme-containing monooxygenase. It is located mainly in the endoplasmic reticulum in the liver and intestine but is also found in the mitochondria in some tissues.  

Micro­somal cytochrome P450 in the endoplasmic reticulum of the liver detoxifies xenobiotics like drugs, carcinogens, and pesti­cides. The cytochrome P450 monooxygenase system hydroxylates these toxins, using NADPH as the source of reducing equivalents. The purpose is to activate or inactivate a drug or to make a toxic compound more soluble, thus facilitating excretion.

Mitochondrial cytochrome P450 systems are found in steroidogenic tissues such as the adrenal cortex, testis, ovary, and placenta and are concerned with the biosynthesis of steroid hormones and cholesterol.

Naturally occurring compounds in foods such as grapefruit also affect cytochrome P450. Grapefruit contains furanocoumarins, which inhibit cytochrome P450 and affect the metabolism of many drugs like statins, omeprazole, antihistamines and benzodiazepenes.

Related Pearl: Heme containing proteins

 Myoglobin   Storage of oxygen in muscle
 Cytochrome C   Involvement in the electron transport chain
 Cytochrome P450  Hydroxylation of xenobiotics

 Tryptophan pyrrolase  Oxidation of tryptophan

questions.text: Which of the following amino acids has an ammonia group in its side chain and is thus likely to be an intermediate of the urea cycle?
questions.solution:
• Arginine is an amino acid having an ammonia side chain and is also part of the urea cycle.
  • Citrulline and ornithine are other important urea cycle intermediates.
  • Aspartate is condensed with citrulline to form argininosuccinate in the urea cycle(Aspartate is not an intermediate)
  • Acetylglutamate is a cofactor in the joining of carbon dioxide with ammonia to form carbamoyl phosphate at the beginning of the urea cycle.

Urea cycle disorders are all characterized by hyperammonemia, encephalopathy, and respiratory alkalosis. There is an accumulation of the precursors of urea - ammonia, and glutamine. They include:

  • Defect in carbamoyl phosphate synthetase I - Hyperammonemia type 1
  • Defect in ornithine transcarbamoylase - Hyperammonemia type 2
  • Defect in argininosuccinate synthetase - Citrullinemia
  • Defect in argininosuccinate lyase- Argininosuccinic aciduria
  • Defect in the gene for arginase- Hyperargininemia 

Related Pearl: Urea Cycle and its disorders

questions.text: In hyaline membrane disease which of the following is deficient in the lungs ?
questions.solution:
Respiratory distress syndrome/Hyaline membrane disease occurs primarily in premature infants (as the baby in this case) due to surfactant deficiency in the alveoli. It is primarily caused by a deficiency of lung surfactant Dipalmitoylphosphatidylcholine (DPPC) or (dipalmitoyl lecithin) which is a Phospholipid.

Neonatal respiratory distress occurs due to insufficient surfactant. It presents as breathlessness with air bronchograms or bilateral ground-glass opacity on X-Ray. Cesarean delivery is a risk factor for neonatal respiratory distress. Antenatal corticosteroids are given to increase the production of surfactant and prevent neonatal respiratory distress.

Dipalmitoyl lecithin is a major component of lung surfactant which comprises mainly of phospholipids. In DPPC, positions 1 & 2 on the glycerol are occupied by palmitate. 

The most important components are

  • Phospholipid - dipalmitoylphosphatidylcholine (DPPC) also known as Dipalmitoyl Lecithin. Lecithin is the most abundant lipid in surfactant.
  • Phosphatidylglycerol- minor component
  • Surfactant apoproteins
  • Calcium ions.
  • 4 unique apoproteins of surfactant: surfactant protein (SP)-A, SP-B, SP-C, and SP-D.

Phospholipid consists of Diglyceride + phosphate + choline or ethanolamine. A phospholipid is any lipid consisting of a diglyceride combined with a phosphate group and a simple organic molecule such as choline or ethanolamine, such as lecithin or cephalin.

Surfactant is secreted by the type 2 pneumocytes in the alveoli. It reduces surface tension at the air-liquid interface of the alveolus.

Clinical correlate :

  • Respiratory distress syndrome (RDS) in preterm neonates is due to insufficient surfactant production.
  • Lung maturity of the fetus can be assessed by determining the ratio of lecithin to sphingomyelin (L:S ratio) in the amniotic fluid. A ratio of >2 indicates maturity.
  • Shake test/Bubble test/Clement test: Formation of stable foam in the presence of surfactant.
  • Phosphatidylglycerol levels in Amniotic fluid.

Phosphatidylethanolamine, also called cephalin, is found in the cell membranes of nervous tissue, particularly in the brain.

Diphosphatidyl glycerol, also called cardiolipin, is found in the inner membrane of mitochondria and plays a key role in apoptosis.

Phosphatidylinositol present in the cell membrane acts as precursors of hormone secondary messengers and platelet-activating factor.

Compound lipids are subclassified based on extra groups as:

  1. Phospholipids (containing phosphoric acid) - Ex: plasmalogens, dipalmitoyl lecithin, cardiolipin, sphingomyelin etc
  2. Non-phosphorylated lipids - Ex: cerebrosides, globosides, gangliosides, sulpholipids etc

questions.text: A 3-month-old infant is brought to the emergency room with seizures. On examination, the child is hypotonic and has hepatomegaly. Investigations reveal elevated uric acid levels in the blood and marked lactic acidosis. The infant is likely to be deficient in
questions.solution:
The clinical features of hypoglycemia, hypertriglyceridemia, hyperuricemia, and lactic acidosis are suggestive of von Gierke disease. It is due to the deficiency of glucose 6-phosphatase (type Ia) or glucose 6-phosphate translocase deficiency (type Ib).

Signs and symptoms include

  • Seizures
  • Doll-like facies (fat cheeks and relatively thin extremities)
  • Hepatomegaly
  • Growth retardation
  • Hypoglycemia (blood glucose <60 mg/dL)
  • Blood uric acid levels >5 mg/dL
  • Lactic acidosis
  • Elevated cholesterol and triglycerides
  • Neutropenia (specific to Ib)

Treatment of von Gierke includes

  • Maintenance of glucose levels by infusion of glucose or the use of uncooked cornstarch (as this is catabolized also by the debranching enzyme).
  • Mild to moderate restriction of lactose, fructose, and sucrose.
  • Ensure adequate intake of vitamins and minerals.
  • Nicotinic acid, fibrates therapy should be started if triglyceride levels are >900 mg/dL, despite dietary therapy.
  • Allopurinol (10 mg/kg/day) should be started for hyperuricemia if uncontrolled on dietary therapy.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman who was on a diet consisting predominantly of packaged and reheated meals presents with iron-deficiency anemia, painful and tender joints, and bleeding manifestations. Which of the following antioxidant deficiency can lead to these symptoms?
questions.solution:
Diet deficient in vitamin C or ascorbic acid, can lead to microcytic-hypochromic anemia, defective collagen synthesis, and bleeding manifestations.

Vitamin C is a water-soluble vitamin. Ascorbic acid cannot be synthesized in human beings because of the absence of L-gulonolactone oxidase. Gooseberries and citrus fruits are rich sources of vitamin C. 

It is mainly required for hydroxylation reactions. It also maintains vitamin E and many metal cofactors (eg. copper) in a reduced state. The active form of vitamin C is ascorbic acid.

Iron absorption is enhanced by vitamin C. It reduces the ferric iron to its ferrous form, thereby helping in the process of absorption of dietary iron from the intestine.

Vitamin C deficiency causes

  • Decreased hydroxylation of proline and lysine, which results in defective collagen synthesis and bleeding manifestations.
  • Decreased absorption of iron leading to microcytic-hypochromic anemia

A deficiency state of vitamin C results in scurvy. Clinical features are:

  • Loose and spongy gums along with loose teeth
  • Swollen joints
  • Hemorrhages
  • Bleeding into the skin - ecchymosis, purpura, petechiae
  • Bone changes
  • Microcytic anemia (due to decreased absorption of iron from the intestine)
  • Scorbutic rosary - sharp, tender beading at the costochondral junctions.

Other options:

Option A- Glutathione is present in glutathione peroxidase. This enzyme acts as an antioxidant. It helps in the destruction of hydrogen peroxide and lipid hydroperoxides.

Option B- β-carotene is provitamin A, found in plants. It helps in the formation of retinaldehyde which is utilized in vision, and retinoic acid which plays a role in the control of gene expression.

Option D- Zinc is an essential component of several metalloenzymes like carboxypeptidases, carbonic anhydrase II, adenosine deaminase, the cytosolic form of superoxide dismutase, etc. Chronic zinc deficiency can cause dwarfism, hypogonadism, dermatitis, and T-cell immunodeficiency. Acrodermatitis enteropathica is an autosomal recessive disorder characterized by abnormalities in zinc absorption.

questions.text: A 15 months old child is brought to the OPD because of developmental delay and clouded appearance of cornea in both eyes. The other examination findings of the child are shown in the image below. The elder sibling of the child also has similar findings. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image shows coarse facial features, umbilical hernia, claw hand, and thoracolumbar gibbus. These features along with corneal opacity are highly suggestive of mucopolysaccharidoses.

Mucopolysaccharidoses (MPS) are a group of genetic disorders affecting the glycosaminoglycans (GAGs). The given features are suggestive of MPS type 1.

The given image shows cloudy cornea in mucopolysaccharidosis:

Other options:

Von Gierke’s disease/ Glycogen storage disease type 1a- Occurs due to the deficiency of glucose-6-phosphatase. It presents with hepatosplenomegaly and fasting hypoglycemia.

Down's syndrome- Occurs due to trisomy 21. It presents with developmental delay and a flattened facial profile but it does not show features like clouded cornea and gibbus.

Refsum disease- It is a disorder of fatty acid metabolism. It occurs due to deficiency of alpha-hydroxylase causing phytanic acid accumulation in the tissues. It presents with neurological symptoms, cerebellar ataxia, retinitis pigmentosa, and polyneuropathy.

questions.text: A worried mother brings her 2-year-old child with the complaints that he hasn't begun walking or talking and says that there is musty odor in the sweat and urine. On examination, there is microcephaly, fair hair, light-colored skin, and blue eyes. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical manifestations point to the diagnosis of Phenylketonuria (PKU).

Phenylketonuria

It is the most common inborn error of amino acid metabolism. It commonly occurs due to a defect in the enzyme phenylalanine hydroxylase (classic phenylketonuria). Less commonly it can also occur due to a defect in dihydropteridin reductase. These defects result in the impaired conversion of phenylalanine to tyrosine. The patient develops clinical features due to elevated levels of phenylalanine metabolites and decreased levels of tyrosine.

Characteristic clinical findings in Phenylketonuria:

  • Mental retardation
  • Failure to walk or talk
  • Seizures
  • Hyperactivity
  • Tremor
  • Microcephaly
  • Failure to grow
  • Deficiency of pigmentation (fair hair, light skin color, and blue eyes)

Oculocutaneous albinism (OCA) is a group of inherited disorders characterized by a reduction or complete lack of melanin pigment in the skin, hair, and eyes.

Its symptoms are albinism with vision problems, which include:

  • Strabismus
  • Photophobia
  • Nystagmus
  • Impaired vision or blindness
  • Astigmatism

Neuropsychiatric manifestations are not seen.

Related Pearl: Phenylketonuria

  1. BH4 - tetrahydrobiopterin (or sapropterin, a synthetic form of BH4)

questions.text: The Image shown below is seen in deficiency of ______
questions.solution:
The above image shows characteristic Casal's necklace pattern, seen in Pellagra, which occur due to deficiency of  Vitamin B3 (niacin).

Niacin deficiency causes pellagra, found mostly among people eating corn/maize-based diets, which is low in niacin and tryptophan.

Niacin can be synthesized in the body from tryptophan. Two compounds- nicotinic acid, and nicotinamide have the biological activity of niacin. The nicotinamide ring of the coenzymes NAD ( nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide) and NADP (nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide phosphate) participate in oxidation/reduction reactions.

The initial symptoms of pellagra include loss of appetite, generalized weakness, irritability, abdominal pain, and vomiting. This is followed by bright red glossitis and a characteristic pigmented, scaly skin rash in sun-exposed areas. This rash is known as Casal’s necklace when it forms a ring around the neck. 

The 4Ds of pellagra:

  • Diarrhea
  • Dermatitis
  • Dementia, leading to
  • Death

It is diagnosed by measuring urinary levels of 2-methyl nicotinamide and 2-pyridone.

It is treated by oral supplementation of 100–200 mg of nicotinamide or nicotinic acid three times daily for 5 days.

questions.text: Which of the following blot transfer techniques is used to detect specific sequences of DNA?
questions.solution:
Southern blot transfer technique can be used to detect specific sequences of DNA. It involves the following steps.

  • DNA from a cell line or tissue is digested into fragments by restriction enzymes
  • The fragments are embedded in agarose or polyacrylamide gel and subjected to electrophoresis. This separates the fragments based on their charge and size
  • The electrophoresed fragments are then denatured with a mild alkali and transferred to nitrocellulose or nylon paper
  • A labelled DNA probe is added, which hybridizes with complementary strands of DNA
  • The hybridisation is visualised by X-raying the film or using an image screen

Other options:

  • Western blot is used to detect and quantify specific protein molecules
  • Northern blot is used to detect and quantify specific RNA molecules
  • South-western blot or overlay blot is used to examine protein-protein or protein-nucleic acid interactions

questions.text: What is the source of morning blood glucose in a person fasting overnight for 12 hours ?
questions.solution:
The source of blood glucose in a person fasting overnight for 11 hours (8 pm to 7 am) is liver glycogenolysis.

First stage of fasting:

The fasting state begins two to four hours after the absorptive/well-fed state. In early fasting i.e; 4-18 hours after the well-fed state, the blood glucose level is maintained by hepatic glycogenolysis. The glycogen stores are sufficient for around 18 hours after a meal following which they start to deplete. So the source of blood glucose in a person fasting for 11 hours will be liver glycogenolysis.

Second stage of fasting:

Gluconeogenesis begins 4–6 hours after the last meal but becomes fully active only after stores of liver glycogen are depleted (after 18 hours). They can serve as a source of glucose for up to 2 days.

Substrates for gluconeogenesis are:

  • Glucogenic amino acids ( mainly alanine) from the muscle and
  • Glycerol from adipose tissue 

During fasting, the glucogenic amino acids are transported to the liver, transaminated into pyruvate, and converted to glucose.

Third stage of fasting:

  • Lipolysis occurs in the adipose tissue due to the activity of hormone-sensitive lipase, stimulated by increased glucagon:insulin ratio.
  • Free fatty acids are the source of energy in this stage and not glucose. Triacylglycerols will be hydrolyzed to fatty acids and glycerol. 
  • Beta oxidation of fatty acids takes place which provides acetyl CoA. 
  • In prolonged starvation (>3 days), acetyl CoA is converted to ketone bodies in the liver which will act as the main fuel source for skeletal and heart muscle and can meet up to 20% of the brain’s energy needs. 

Final stage of fasting:

After several weeks of starvation, ketone body synthesis will not take place due to depleted triacylglycerol stores. Proteins remain the only source of fuel. Protein degradation increases, and death results from a loss of heart, liver, or kidney function.

Role of insulin and glucagon:

When blood glucose falls during fasting, there is increased secretion of glucagon and decreased release of insulin. Hence glucagon:insulin ratio is increased.

Effects of increased glucagon:insulin ratio on enzymes of glycogenolysis and gluconeogenesis:

Metabolic process         Fasting state      Fed state
Glucagon: insulin   Increased              Decreased
Gluconeogenesis    Increased                Decreased            
Glycogenolysis  Increased                Decreased
Ketogenesis  Increased                Decreased
Glycogen storage  Decreased  Increased             

Other options:

Option C: Muscle glycogen cannot contribute directly to plasma glucose, since muscle lacks glucose-6-phosphatase. So glycogen cannot be converted to glucose to be used as fuel during starvation. 

Option D: In the well-fed state/ absorptive state of two to four hours after a meal, dietary glucose is the main source of fuel.

questions.text: A nutritionist is studying the blood levels of various lipoproteins. One of the samples shows the elevation of LDL and total cholesterol. Which of the following might be the possible cause?
questions.solution:
Type 2 hyperlipoproteinemia shows increased levels of LDL and total cholesterol.

It occurs due to a defect in LDL receptors. Defective LDL receptors cause a decrease in uptake of LDL and cholesterol. As a result, the blood levels of both of this rise.

LDL receptor (apo B100 and apo E) are expressed on a multiple types of cells. They are expressed when the cell needs cholesterol for metabolic needs. LDL molecule binds to this receptor and is endocytosed. 

It is a tightly regulated step and involves PCSK9. Therapy targetting PCSK9 have been developed to control the blood levels of LDL.

questions.text: Which of the following mineral is absorbed by the following mechanism?
questions.solution:
The given image shows the absorption of iron from a duodenal enterocyte by mucosal block theory.

Iron Absorption :

Iron is mainly absorbed from the duodenum and proximal small intestine. The acidic contents of the stomach play a major role in absorption. Once it reaches the brush border of the absorbing cell, the ferric form is converted to ferrous form by ferrireductase. This ferrous form is then transported into the cell by divalent metal transporter type 1. (DMT-1)

Once inside the cell, iron may be stored as ferritin or transported to plasma through ferroportin. During the transport, iron is converted back into the ferric form by hephaestin and ceruloplasmin. The iron in plasma is then transferred to the required tissues with the help of protein transferrin. Iron is a major content of hemoglobin, myoglobin, cytochrome P-450 group of enzymes, components of electron transport chain, and ribonucleotide reductase.

Clinical significance - Iron is available in food in two forms, heme and nonheme. Heme iron is mainly present in red meat and is readily absorbed.

Iron absorption in the duodenum is mainly regulated by hepcidin. It inhibits ferroportin and suppresses the release of iron from macrophages which is used by erythroid precursors to make hemoglobin. High hepcidin levels are seen in systemic inflammation and low hepcidin levels are seen in hemochromatosis.

Iron is an important component of

  • Hemoglobin
  • Myoglobin
  • Cytochrome P450 groups of enzymes
  • Components of the electron transport chain
  • Ribonucleotide reductase

questions.text: A 12-year-old girl, a known case of type 1 diabetes mellitus presents to the emergency room with severe nausea, vomiting and abdominal pain. She is currently hyperglycemic and urine Rothera's test is positive. Which of the following metabolic hubs of the body, cannot utilize the non-carbohydrate metabolic byproduct that is used for energy production in this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette with a positive Rothera's test (urine ketone bodies-positive) is suggestive of diabetic ketoacidosis. It is a metabolic state of the body with increased production of ketones (the non-carbohydrate metabolic byproduct) used for energy production in this patient's condition. RBCs and the liver cannot utilize ketone bodies.

Type I diabetes mellitus is a low insulin state. There is an increased conversion of fatty acids to acetyl-CoA which in turn leads to increased ketone body production. Acetyl-CoA is a precursor of ketone bodies. The presence of ketosis can be established by the detection of ketone bodies in urine by Rothera's test. Supportive evidence may be derived from an estimation of serum electrolytes, acid-base parameters, glucose and urea estimation.

The ketone bodies synthesized in the liver mitochondria are transported in the blood to the peripheral tissues, where they are utilized by the following steps:

  1. β-hydroxybutyrate is oxidized to acetoacetate by β-hydroxybutyrate dehydrogenase producing NADH.
  2. Acetoacetate is then activated to acetoacetyl CoA by transferring a CoA molecule from succinyl CoA by succinyl CoA-acetoacetate CoA transferase (thiophorase).
  3. Acetoacetyl CoA is cleaved into two acetyl CoA molecules by thiolase and oxidized into CO2 by the TCA cycle.

Ketone bodies are utilised by extrahepatic tissue like the cardiac muscle and renal cortex (prefer the ketone bodies to glucose as fuel). Tissues like skeletal muscle and brain can also utilise the ketone bodies as alternate sources of energy, if glucose is not available.

RBCs cannot utilize ketone bodies as they lack mitochondria. The liver cannot utilize ketone bodies as it lacks the enzyme thiophorase.

Related Pearl: Ketogenesis

Related Pearl: Ketone body utilisation

1. 3-Hydroxybutyrate dehydrogenase

2. CoA Transferase

3. Thiolase

questions.text: Cyanide blocks citric acid cycle by blocking which of the following ?
questions.solution:
Cyanide blocks citric acid cycle by blocking NAD+.

Cyanide blocks complex 4 of the electron transport chain, thereby directly inhibiting electron transport, causing ↓ proton gradient and block ATP synthesis.

As a result electron carriers NADH and FADH cannot unload their electrons, thus reducing the concentration of NAD+ and FAD+ which is required for the Kreb’s cycle to proceed.

questions.text: A 57-year-old male presents with anasarca, nephrotic range proteinuria, and mild hepatomegaly. A biopsy specimen seen under polarised light shows the following appearance. What is the most likely stain used here?
questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of systemic Amyloidosis. The image shows a congo-red stained biopsy specimen with apple-green birefringence under polarized light, diagnostic of amyloidosis.

Amyloidosis refers to extracellular deposits of fibrillar proteins. Abnormal fibrils are produced by the aggregation of misfolded proteins. Amyloid appears as an amorphous, eosinophilic, hyaline, extracellular substance.

Kidneys are the most frequently involved with heart being second. Cardiac involvement is the leading cause of death from AL amyloidosis. 

Renal amyloidosis usually manifests as proteinuria, often in the nephrotic range, and is associated with hypoalbuminemia, secondary hypercholesterolemia, hypertriglyceridemia, and edema or anasarca. 

The image shows a congo-red stained biopsy specimen with (A) focal positive staining (orange-red) of amorphous extracellular material, and (B) apple-green birefringence under polarized light, diagnostic of amyloidosis. 

Other options: 

Perl's Prussian blue stain is used in Hemochromatosis to stain liver tissue which shows blue stained hepatocellular iron.

 

Acid mucin is stained by Alcian blue. 

 

The given slide shows the GI mucosa, which has been stained with Warthin-Starry silver stain, demonstrating the bacilli (Helicobacter pylori).

questions.text: A 35-year-man presents with nosebleeds, bleeding gums and multiple ecchymoses. Lab investigations show Hb: 8.5, Platelet count: 12, 000 and Total leucocyte count: 52,000 with 83% blasts as seen below. The blasts are CD33+. The most likely diagnosis is ______

choices.text: Chronic Lymphocytic leukemia / Small Lymphocytic lymphoma (CLL/SLL)

questions.solution:
The morphology of blasts with abundant cytoplasm, fine azurophilic granules and Auer rods, delicate nuclear chromatin with 1-4 prominent nucleoli on peripheral smear and CD33 positivity suggest a diagnosis of acute myeloid leukemia (AML).

The 2016 WHO classification of acute myeloid leukemia (AML):

  • AML with recurrent genetic abnormalities 
  • AML with myelodysplasia-related changes
  • Therapy-related myeloid neoplasms 
  • AML, not otherwise specified
  • Myeloid sarcoma 
  • Myeloid proliferations of Down syndrome

AML is a tumor of hematopoietic progenitors caused by acquired oncogenic mutations that impede differentiation, leading to the accumulation of immature myeloid blasts in the marrow. It occurs at all ages, but the incidence rises throughout life, peaking after 60 years of age. Occasionally, blasts are entirely absent from the blood (aleukemic leukemia). Bone marrow examination is essential to exclude acute leukemia in pancytopenic patients

Related Pearl: WHO classification of Acute Myeloid Leukemia

The WHO system divides acute myeloid leukemia (AML) into several groups:

AML with certain genetic abnormalities (gene or chromosome changes)

  • AML with a translocation between chromosomes 8 and 21 [t(8;21)]
  • AML with a translocation or inversion in chromosome 16 [t(16;16) or inv(16)]
  • APL with the PML-RARA fusion gene
  • AML with a translocation between chromosomes 9 and 11 [t(9;11)]
  • AML with a translocation between chromosomes 6 and 9 [t(6:9)]
  • AML with a translocation or inversion in chromosome 3 [t(3;3) or inv(3)]
  • AML (megakaryoblastic) with a translocation between chromosomes 1 and 22 [t(1:22)]
  • AML with the BCR-ABL1 (BCR-ABL) fusion gene*
  • AML with mutated NPM1 gene
  • AML with biallelic mutations of the CEBPA gene (that is, mutations in both copies of the gene)
  • AML with mutated RUNX1 gene*

*This is still a "provisional entity," meaning it is not yet clear if there's enough evidence that it is a unique group.

AML with myelodysplasia-related changes

AML related to previous chemotherapy or radiation

AML not otherwise specified (This includes cases of AML that do not fall into one of the above groups and is similar to the FAB classification.)

  • AML with minimal differentiation (FAB M0)
  • AML without maturation (FAB M1)
  • AML with maturation (FAB M2)
  • Acute myelomonocytic leukemia (FAB M4)
  • Acute monoblastic/monocytic leukemia (FAB M5)
  • Pure erythroid leukemia (FAB M6)
  • Acute megakaryoblastic leukemia (FAB M7)
  • Acute basophilic leukemia
  • Acute panmyelosis with fibrosis

Myeloid sarcoma (also known as granulocytic sarcoma or chloroma)

Myeloid proliferations related to Down syndrome

Undifferentiated and biphenotypic acute leukemias are not strictly AML, but are leukemias that have both lymphocytic and myeloid features. They are sometimes called mixed phenotype acute leukemias (MPALs).

questions.text: A 12 year-old-boy, who is a known case of atopic dermatitis, went to play in a nearby farm after which he developed runny nose and sneezing. His symptoms subsided after he came back home. But he developed the same symptoms again on the next day even without going to the farm. These symptoms occurring on the next day are chiefly mediated by:
questions.solution:
The given scenario describes pollen allergy. Development of symptoms again without a second exposure to the allergen is known as late phase reaction of allergic response. This is chiefly mediated by leukocyte infiltration into the tissues, especially the eosinophils. 

Allergic response/ type 1 hypersensitivity usually develops within minutes of exposure to the allergen. This response is chiefly mediated by the activation of mast cells. But, in some cases, there is a seond response that develops 2 to 24 hours after the exposure to allergen. This second response does not require second exposure to the allergen. This is known as late phase reaction. This occurs because of the leukocyte infiltration of the tissues which also keeps this response continued for many days.

questions.text: Burkitt lymphoma is associated with which chromosomal translocation?
questions.solution:
Burkitt lymphoma, also known as small non-cleaved-cell lymphoma, is a highly aggressive B-cell non-Hodgkin lymphoma characterized by the translocation and deregulation of the c-myc gene on chromosome 8.

The classic t(8;14)(q24;q32) reciprocal translocation results in the transposition of the c-myc proto-oncogene on chromosome 8 with one of the immunoglobulin heavy chain (IGH) genes on chromosome 14, which results in activation of the c-myc gene and is considered responsible for tumor proliferation.

As a result, the MYC coding sequence is intact with the loss of regulatory control. The activation of the proto-oncogene leads to overexpression of the MYC protein, which is responsible for the pathogenesis of Burkitt lymphoma.

questions.text: Graft from identical twin is called:
questions.solution:
A graft from an identical twin is called isograft.

Isograft is defined as an organ or tissue that is taken from an individual (donor) and is placed on another individual (recipient) who has the same genetic constitution as of the donor. Example, graft between identical twins.

Organ implanted in a different anatomic location.

Xenotransplant Transfer of cells/tissues/organs in a different species.

questions.text: Nut-meg liver is seen in ________.
questions.solution:
Congestive hepatopathy, also known as nutmeg liver and chronic passive congestion of the liver, is liver dysfunction due to venous congestion; it usually occurs due to congestive heart failure.

Pathogenesis:

  • It is seen in patients with chronic cardiac lesions, especially those affecting the right heart (e.g., right-sided heart failure), which causes the blood being damped back into the inferior vena cava and then into the hepatic veins.
  • This leads to increased pressure in the sublobular branches of the hepatic veins, which causes an engorgement of venous blood.

Gross appearance:

  • In chronic passive hepatic congestion due to heart failure, the centrilobular regions are grossly red-brown due to congestion and slightly depressed (because of cell death) and are accentuated against the surrounding zones of uncongested tan liver (nutmeg liver).
  • The appearance is called nutmeg liver pattern due to its close resemblance with the cut surface of the nutmeg seed.

The image below liver with gross appearance as described above along with cut section of the nutmeg seed on top left corner.

Microscopic appearance:

Microscopic examination reveals centrilobular hemorrhage, hemosiderin-laden macrophages, and variable degrees of hepatocyte dropout and necrosis.

questions.text: Which of the following factors do not play a role in the termination of acute inflammatory response is?
questions.solution:
Interleukin 6 does not play a role in the termination of acute inflammatory response as it is a pro-inflammatory cytokine.

Factors that contribute to the termination of acute inflammatory response:

  • Anti-inflammatory cytokines- IL-10 and TGF-β.
  • Neutrophils have short half-lives in tissues and die by apoptosis within hours to a day or two after leaving the blood. 
  • Mediators of inflammation are produced in rapid bursts and have short half-lives.

questions.text: Thrombosis is initiated by:
questions.solution:
Thrombosis is initiated by endothelial injury.

Three primary abnormalities, often referred to as Virchow triad, are known to induce thrombosis. They include:

  • Endothelial injury
  • Stasis or turbulent blood flow
  • Hypercoagulability of the blood

Of these, endothelial injury is the most important factor.

questions.text: When you are going through the case sheets of the patients admitted in your unit during your internship, you notice the following pedigree chart attached to one of the files. Which of the following diseases is the patient likely to have?
questions.solution:
The pedigree is representative of an autosomal dominant type of inheritance. Of the options mentioned, Huntington's disease shows an autosomal dominant pattern.

In the autosomal dominant pattern of inheritance, both males and females are equally affected, and the affected individual has a 50% chance of passing it on to the offspring.

The following flow chart helps in making out the pattern of inheritance from a given pedigree chart.

Other options:

Option B: Sickle cell anemia shows an autosomal recessive mode of inheritance
Option C: Hemophilia A shows an X linked recessive mode of inheritance
Option D:Rett syndrome shows an X linked dominant mode of inheritance.

Related Pearl: Pedigree chart for different inheritance patterns

 

Autosomal Dominant Disorders:

  • With every autosomal dominant disorder, some patients do not have affected parents. Such patients owe their disorder to new mutations involving either the egg or the sperm from which they were derived.
  • Clinical features can be modified by variations in penetrance and expressivity.
  • In many conditions, the age at onset is delayed, and symptoms and signs may not appear until adulthood (as in Huntington disease).

X-linked Recessive Conditions:

  • All sex-linked disorders are X-linked, and almost all are recessive.
  • Several genes are located in the “male-specific region of Y;” all these are related to spermatogenesis.
  • Males with mutations affecting the Y-linked genes are usually infertile, and hence, there is no Y-linked inheritance.
  • An affected male does not transmit the disorder to his sons, but all daughters are carriers.
  • Sons of heterozygous women have, of course, a one-in-two chance of receiving the mutant gene.
  • Heterozygous females express the disorder partially because of random inactivation of one X chromosome.

Related Pearl: Autosomal Dominant Disorders

A Very Powerful DOMINANT Human

  • Very: von Willebrand disease
