questions.text: A change in the respiratory tract lining from columnar epithelium  to stratified squamous epithelium is called as?
questions.solution:
The change described in the question is called metaplasia.

Metaplasia is defined as a reversible change in which one type of differentiated cell is replaced by another type.

Examples of metaplasia include:

  • Columnar to squamous epithelium (also called squamous metaplasia):
    • This is the most common type of metaplasia, and is usually seen in the respiratory tract in cases of chronic smoking or sometimes in vitamin A deficiency,
    • It may also be present in cases where there are stones in the excretory ducts of salivary glands, pancreas, or bile ducts, where, the normal secretory columnar epithelium is replaced by stratified squamous epithelium.
  • Squamous to columnar epithelium (also called columnar metaplasia): It is seen in Barrett's oesophagus.
  • Connective tissue metaplasia: It refers to the formation of bone, cartilage, or adipose tissue in the tissues where they are normally absent. One such example is myositis ossificans, a condition where there is the formation of bone within the muscle.

questions.text: A 33-year-old male presented with a 2 cm thyroid nodule and a solitary, non-tender, and firm nodule on the left side of his neck. Thyroid function tests are within normal limits. The histology of the tumour is given below. Identify the incorrect statement regarding this condition?

choices.text: They generally have a poor prognosis.
The most common variant is the follicular variant.
BRAF mutation is the most common mutation in this condition
They present as cold masses on thyroid scintigraphy.

questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario and histopathological slide showing branching papillae lined by epithelial cells with clear ground glass or Orphan Annie eye nuclei, fibrovascular cores, and psammoma bodies suggest the diagnosis of papillary carcinoma of the thyroid. Papillary thyroid cancers  usually have an excellent prognosis.

BRAF mutation is the most common mutation in papillary thyroid cancer and is associated with lymph node metastases and a higher recurrence rate. One third to one-half of papillary thyroid carcinomas harbour a gain-of-function mutation in the BRAF gene. The RET mutations are present in approximately 20% to 40% of papillary thyroid cancers.

They present as cold masses on thyroid scintigraphy.

The most common variant is the follicular variant, which has the characteristic nuclear features of papillary carcinoma but a follicular architecture.

Microscopic Features of Papillary carcinoma of  thyroid.

  • Complex, branching, randomly oriented papillae with fibrovascular cores associated with follicles.
  • Usually dense fibrosis.
  • Papillae lined by cuboidal cells.
  • Nuclei are overlapping with finely dispersed optically clear chromatin (also called ground-glass), which gives a clear or empty appearance, therefore,the name ground glass or Orphan Annie eye nuclei.
  • Macronucleoli, eosinophilic intranuclear inclusions (represent cytoplasmic invaginations) and nuclear longitudinal grooves (represent folding of the redundant nuclear membrane, but nonspecific).
  • Stromal elastosis in 66% - often lymphatic invasion.
  • Psammoma bodies.

 

Papillary thyroid cancers have an excellent prognosis, with a 10-year survival rate around 95%. The prognosis of papillary thyroid cancer depends on
several factors like age (less favorable for patients older than 40 years), the presence of extrathyroidal extension, and stage of the tumor (presence of distant metastases).

Related Pearl: Papillary thyroid carcinoma

  • Papillary carcinoma is the most common thyroid carcinoma.
  • Most common in iodine sufficient areas, children and in those exposed to ionizing radiation. 
  • Mean age of presentation is 3rd-4th decade; more common in women than men (2:1)
  • Usually cold nodule on the scan
  • Branching papillae and follicles with the fibrovascular stalk, Psammoma bodies
  • Nuclear changes: Optically clear - Ground glass or Orphan Annie eye nuclei, pseudo-inclusions, nuclear grooves.
  • Lymph node metastasis is common
  • Lateral aberrant thyroid denotes a cervical lymph node invaded by papillary carcinoma.
  • Dysphagia, dysphonia and dyspnea are associated with local invasion
  • Most common sites of metastasis : lung > liver > bone > brain
  • Excellent prognosis, with a 10-year survival rate in excess of 95%.

questions.text: A 10-year-old male child presents with a history of easy bruisiability and hemarthrosis. Investigations revealed normal platelet count and bleeding time, normal PT, and prolonged PTT. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The symptom of hemarthrosis and the investigations are suggestive of a coagulation disorder. Among the given options, hemophilia A is a coagulation disorder, while all the other conditions are platelet disorders.

Bleeding into joints (hemarthrosis) and deep tissues is a feature of coagulation disorders, whereas platelet disorders usually present with mucocutaneous bleeding such as petechiae, purpura, epistaxis, or GI bleed. Prolonged PT/aPTT is a feature of coagulation disorders, while prolonged bleeding time is a feature of platelet disorders.

In the given scenario, normal platelet count and bleeding time exclude platelet disorders. Normal PT indicates normal functioning of the extrinsic pathway of the coagulation cascade, and prolonged PTT indicates a defect in the intrinsic pathway.

Hemophilia is an X-linked (recessive) coagulation disorder associated with mutations in factor VIII, affecting the intrinsic pathway. The patients present with easy bruising, significant hemorrhage following trauma and operative procedures, and hemarthroses, but no petechiae. The diagnosis is confirmed by carrying out factor VIII-specific assays. Infusions of recombinant factor VIII are used for treatment. 

Other options:

Option 1- Von Willebrand disease is an autosomal dominant disorder that is associated with qualitative/quantitative defects in the von Willebrand factor (vWF). vWF is a protein necessary for platelet adhesion, platelet aggregation, and stabilization of factor VIII.

Option 3- Bernard-Soulier disease is an autosomal recessive condition that is characterized by the absence of the GpIb receptor necessary for platelet adhesion to the subendothelial collagen. 

Option 4- Glanzmann's thrombasthenia is an autosomal recessive condition that is characterized by the absence of the GpIIb/IIIa receptor necessary for platelet aggregation.

questions.text: What is your diagnosis with respect to the findings shown in the peripheral smear given below?
questions.solution:
The haemogram findings, peripheral smear showing macro-ovalocytes and hypersegmented neutrophil are suggestive of Megaloblastic anemia. Vitamin B12 deficiency is a cause of megaloblastic anaemia.

Megaloblastic anemia has hypersegmented neutrophil, with five or more nuclear lobules instead of the normal three to four.

Megablastic anaemia:  There is impairment of DNA synthesis that leads to ineffective hematopoiesis and distinctive morphologic changes, including abnormally large erythroid precursors and red cells.

Peripheral smear:

  • Macro-ovalocytes
  • Most macrocytes lack the central pallor of normal red cells and even appear hyperchromic, but the MCHC is not elevated.
  • The reticulocyte count is low.
  • Nucleated red cell progenitors occasionally appear in the circulating blood when anemia is severe.
  • Neutrophils are also larger than normal (macro polymorphonuclear) and show nuclear hypersegmentation, having five or more nuclear lobules.

Marrow:

  • Markedly hypercellular as a result of increased hematopoietic precursors.
  • Sieve like pattern of chromatin of immature precursors (Megaloblasts)
  • Granulocytic precursors also display dysmaturation in the form of giant metamyelocytes and band forms.
  • Megakaryocytes, too, can be abnormally large and have bizarre, multilobate nuclei.
  • The derangement in DNA synthesis causes most precursors to undergo apoptosis in the marrow (ineffective hematopoiesis) and leads to pancytopenia.

Related Pearl: Causes of Megaloblastic Anemia

Vitamin B12 Deficiency causes:

  • Decreased Intake
    • Inadequate diet
    • Vegetarianism
  • Impaired Absorption
    • Intrinsic factor deficiency
    • Pernicious anemia
    • Gastrectomy
    • Malabsorption states
    • Diffuse intestinal disease (e.g., lymphoma, systemic sclerosis)
    • Ileal resection
    • Ileitis
  • Competitive parasitic uptake
    • Fish tapeworm infestation
    • Bacterial overgrowth in blind loops and diverticula of bowel

Folic Acid Deficiency causes:

  • Decreased Intake
    • Inadequate diet
    • Alcoholism
    • Infancy
  • Impaired Absorption
    • Malabsorption states
    • Intrinsic intestinal disease
    • Anticonvulsants
    • Oral contraceptives
  • Increased Loss
    • Hemodialysis
  • Increased Requirement
    • Pregnancy, infancy
    • Disseminated cancer
    • Markedly increased hematopoiesis
  • Impaired Utilization
    • Folic acid antagonists
    • Unresponsive to vitamin B12 or folic acid therapy
    • Metabolic inhibitors of DNA synthesis and/or folate metabolism

questions.text: Which of the following organisms is seen in the given gram stain image?
questions.solution:
The gram stain shows gram-positive, club-shaped rods, which indicate Corynebacterium diphtheriae.

Clinical correlate:

  • Diphtheria toxin is absorbed into the mucous membrane causing destruction of epithelium leading to pseudomembrane formation, myocarditis and tubular necrosis in kidneys.
  • Inﬂammation begins in the respiratory tract causing a sore throat and low-grade fever. Dyspnea soon follows because of the obstruction caused by the membrane.

 

The following image shows Staphylococcus (gram-positive cocci) in clusters:

The following image shows Streptococci (gram-positive cocci) in chains:

questions.text: A patient presents with the following skin lesion. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a skin lesion that is red, edematous, and well-demarcated from the surrounding skin. These features are suggestive of erysipelas. 

Erysipelas is a skin infection involving superficial lymphatics. It is caused by streptococcus. It presents as erythematous, indurated, and inflamed skin lesions.

Staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome is caused by the exfoliative toxin and presents with peeling of the affected skin.

Necrotizing fasciitis is a streptococcal infection involving the fascial planes. The lesions show dark areas of necrosis along with erythema.

Gas gangrene is a form of myonecrosis. It is a bacterial infection in which tissue gas is produced in gangrene. It is usually caused by Clostridium perfringens. The given image of gas gangrene shows necrotic bullae, erythema, and edema:

Related Pearl: Skin and soft tissue lesions caused by Streptococcus

Streptococcus causes a variety of skin and soft tissue infections. These include:

a. Impetigo- Infection of superficial layers of the skin. It presents as superficial vesicles which break down and are then encrusted by honey-colored scab. It usually occurs in children.

The given image shows impetigo:

 

b. Erysipelas- Infection of the superficial epidermis. It presents as an erythematous raised lesion with sharply demarcated edges that differentiate it from the surrounding skin. 

The given image shows erysipelas- note the clear demarcation at the nasolabial folds seen in facial erysipelas.

 

c. Cellulitis- Infection of the skin and subcutaneous tissue. It presents with erythema and edema. It can be differentiated from erysipelas by - i. Erysipelas is a raised lesion whereas cellulitis is not, ii. Cellulitis is poorly demarcated from the surrounding skin whereas erysipelas is clearly demarcated.

The given image shows cellulitis:

 

d. Necrotizing fasciitis- Infection involving the fascial planes. It presents with dark areas of necrosis, erythema, and edema.

The given image shows necrotizing fasciitis with areas of erythema and necrosis:

 

d. Myositis and myonecrosis- Infection of the muscle.

The given image shows necrotizing myositis:

questions.text: A 2 year old child is brought to the OPD with oral and perioral lesions as seen in the image below. Similar lesions were also found on his palms and soles. What is the probable causative organism?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the image are suggestive of hand, foot, and mouth disease that is caused by coxsackie A virus.

Hand, foot, and mouth disease initially begins with fever and sore throat following which blisters develop over the oral cavity, hands and feet.

It usually occurs in children but may also occur in adults. It is a self limiting disease and subsides in 1-2 weeks.

The following images show lesions affecting hands and feet:

 

Another condition that causes red sores around the mouth and the nose is impetigo. It forms a characteristic honey coloured scab. It is caused by Streptococcus, especially in children. It is not associated with lesions on palms and soles. The given image shows impetigo:

questions.text: A 12-year-old girl presents with severe  fever,headache and photophobia. On examination,nuchal rigidity,Kernig's and Brudzinski signs were positive. CSF examination shows reduced glucose, increased protein, and increased leukocytes with the predominance of neutrophils. Gram staining of the CSF is shown below. Causative organism is
questions.solution:
History and physical examination findings are suggestive of bacterial meningitis. The given image shows intracellular gram-negative diplococci i.e. Neisseria meningitidis.

Fever, convulsions, and signs of meningeal irritation (nuchal rigidity, Kernig's sign, Brudzinski's signs) in a child, with CSF showing reduced glucose, increased protein, and increased leukocytes levels is a typical presentation of bacterial meningitis.

Pathogenesis & clinical features:

  • The organism enters the body through the nasopharynx by attaching to the epithelial cells with the help of pili. From nasopharynx, they enter the bloodstream producing bacteremia, and the symptoms may resemble upper respiratory tract infection.
  • Fulminant meningococcemia is the severe form, where the patient presents with high-grade fever and hemorrhagic rash. There is thrombosis of several small blood vessels in various organs with perivascular infiltration and petechial haemorrhages. 
  • Some patients with fulminant meningococcemia may also develop disseminated intravascular coagulation, and circulatory collapse, a condition known as Waterhouse–Friderichsen syndrome.

CSF findings in different types of meningitis

Parameter/ Meningitis Bacterial  Tubercular  Viral 
CSF pressure Raised Raised Raised
Appearance Turbid Clear (cob-web formation) Clear
Glucose Decreased Decreased Normal
Protein High Very high slightly high
Cells Neutrophils Lymphocytes Lymphocytes

 Guidelines for prophylaxis:

  • All patients admitted to the hospital with meningitis should be placed on standard precautions.
  • Droplet precautions are recommended for patients with Neisseria meningitidis and Haemophilus influenzae type b (Hib) meningitis until they have received 24 hours of effective therapy. 
  • Chemoprophylaxis is indicated for the household and close contacts. The preferred antibiotics are rifampin, ciprofloxacin, and ceftriaxone.
  • Monovalent, polyvalent, and conjugate vaccines are availbale.

Option a: Haemophilus influenzae type B is a gram-negative bacillus. In CSF, long bacillary filamentous forms predominate. H. influenzae b grows on chocolate agar (which supplies necessary nutrients from lysed red blood cells) or as satellite colonies surrounding β-hemolytic colonies of S. aureus on blood agar.

Option c: Streptococcus pneumoniae is a gram positive, capsulated, flame shaped or lanceolate shaped diplococci.

Option d: Listeria monocytogenes is a gram positive bacillus.

questions.text: All  the following statements are true regarding the COVID-19 virus, except?

choices.text: It is an enveloped RNA virus

questions.solution:
Positive sense RNA is seen in the causative virus.

Properties of Coronaviridae family:

  • They have enveloped RNA viruses.
  • They contain a genome of single-stranded and positive-sense RNA
  • They have helical nucleocapsid

The following image shows the structure of coronavirus :

The gold standard for its diagnosis is the identification of viral genome targets in the respiratory tract materials by reverse transcriptase polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR).

RT-PCR involves the reverse transcription of the genetic material of the virus (RNA) to complementary DNA (cDNA), followed by amplification of some regions of the cDNA. Four regions of the SARS CoV2 genome are used as targets:

  • RdRp gene (RNA-dependent RNA polymerase) 
  • Genes from structural proteins 
    • E (virus envelope) 
    • N (virus nucleocapsid), 
  • ORF1ab gene (open reading frame 1a and 1b)

questions.text: A 70-year- old woman was diagnosed with right leg cellulitis and was admitted in hospital for 3 days. She was prescribed clindamycin. Two days after her discharge, she developed fever, diarrhoea and abdominal pain and blood reports are Hb- 12g/dl; WBC count -18,000/mm3; CRP-160mg/l. What is the most probable etiological agent?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette of a patient with hospital- acquired diarrhea (nosocomial) following antibiotic administration is suggestive of Pseudomembranous colitis due to Clostridium difficile. 

Clostridium difficile infection:

Clostridium difficile is the most common cause of infectious diarrhea in nosocomial infection. 

It is the most common antibiotic-associated diarrhea. It is commonly seen in individuals who receive a prolonged antibiotic course, which causes a change in the composition of gastrointestinal microbial flora, leading to colonization of C. difficile.

Clinical features:

  • Lower abdominal pain with loose watery diarrhea.
  • Fever, leukocytosis
  • In some patients, the disease may progress to life-threatening pseudomembranous colitis.

Investigations:

  • Nucleic acid amplification tests, including PCR assays, for C. difficile toxin A or B gene in stool 
  • Stool Culture in selective media
  • Demonstrating Toxin by Hep-2 cell cultures
  • Toxin gene identification by Enzyme immunoassay
  • Colonscopy or sigmoidoscopy reveals characteristic appearance, with erythema, white plaques, or an adherent pseudomembrane.

Despite the array of tests available for C. difficile and its toxins, no single traditional test has high sensitivity, high specificity, and rapid turnaround.

Most laboratory tests for toxins, including enzyme immunoassays, lack sensitivity.

Nucleic acid amplification tests, including PCR assays, for C. difficile toxin A or B gene in stool have now been approved for diagnostic purposes and appear to be both rapid and sensitive while retaining high specificity.

 TREATMENT:

Oral vancomycin, metronidazole,and fidaxomicin are used for the treatment of pseudomembranous colitis, depending on its severity. 

First choice treatment of C. difficile colitis:

Severity Treatment
Mild to moderate Oral Vancomycin
Severe (WBC >15,000/cu.mm, Creatinine >1.5 times baseline) Oral Vancomycin
Severe, Complicated (Shock, Ileus, Toxic Megacolon) Oral Vancomycin + IV Metronidazole ± Rectal Vancomycin
Recurrent/ multiple episodes Fecal Microbiota Transplantation (FMT)

*Fidaxomicin is an alternative in all cases.

*Metronidazole now reserved for non-severe infections in settings where access to first-line drugs is limited or cost is an issue. 

Recent update: Harrison's 20th edition recommends the use of vancomycin over metronidazole in the treatment of initial episodes which are mild to moderate in severity. Metronidazole is recommended only if vancomycin or fidaxomicin are not accessible. Oral metronidazole is less effective than the other options and may necessitate a longer treatment course for response.

Other options: Escherichia coli, Norovirus, Rotavirus are all causes of Traveller's diarrhea.

Other causes for Nosocomial diarrhea:

  • Clostridium perfringens,
  • Klebsiella oxytoca,
  • Staphylococcus aureus.

Related Pearl: Diagnostic criteria for Clostridium difficile infection

 

The diagnosis of CDI is based on a combination of clinical criteria:

1.Diarrhea (≥3 unformed stools per 24 h for ≥2 days) with no other recognized cause      

2.Detection of toxins A or B in the stool by PCR or culture

               or               

 Detection of pseudomembranes in the colon

questions.text: A 21-year-old male patient presents with recurrent bouts of vomiting and abdominal cramps over the past three hours. He gives a history of consumption of fried rice at a Chinese restaurant 5 hours back. Which of the following is the most probable causative organism?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette showing food poisoning within 2 hours of consumption of fried rice/ Chinese street food is strongly suggestive of Bacillus cereus (Serotypes 1, 3, 5) food poisoning

B. cereus produces lecithinase and ferments glucose but not mannitol.

Two mechanisms of action have been described for the enterotoxin of B.cereus, one involving stimulation of the cyclic adenosine monophosphate (cAMP) system and the other independent of it.

Food poisoning after eating food contaminated with Bacillus cereus is of two types.

Bacillus cereus Diarrheal type Emetic type
Incubation period 8-16 hours 1-5 hours
Toxin Secreted in intestine Preformed
Heat Heat labile Heat stable
Food items Meat Rice
Clinical feature Diarrhoea, abdominal cramps Vomiting, abdominal cramps

For diagnosis, the presence of 1,00,000 or more bacteria per gram of stool is diagnostic, as anything less than that may be present as normal flora in the gut. Both types of illnesses are mild and self-limiting, requiring no specific treatment.

Other options:

Option A: Food poisoning by C.perfringens is usually caused by a cold or warmed-up meat dish. When contaminated meat is cooked, the spores in the interior may survive. During storage or warming, they germinate and multiply in the anaerobic environment of the cooked meat. Large numbers of clostridia may thus be consumed, which may pass unharmed by gastric acid due to the high protein content of the meat and reach the intestines where they produce the enterotoxin. After an incubation period of 8-24 hours, abdominal pain, diarrhea and vomiting set in. Diagnosis is made by isolating heat-resistant C.perfringens type A from feces and food.

Option B: Enterotoxigenic E.coli is endemic in developing countries of the tropics, seen in all age groups. Its severity varies from mild watery diarrhea to a fatal disease indistinguishable from cholera. It has an incubation period of >16 hours. Diagnosis of ETEC diarrhea depends on demonstration of the enterotoxins.

Option C: Staphylococcus aureus enterotoxin is responsible for the manifestations of staphylococcal food poisoning-nausea, vomiting and diarrhea 2-6 hours after consuming food contaminated by the preformed toxin. About two-thirds of S.aureus strains, growing in carbohydrate and protein food, secrete the toxin. Meat and fish or milk and milk products cooked and left at room temperature after contamination with staphylococci, for enough time for the toxin to accumulate, are the common items responsible. The source of infection is usually a food handler who is a carrier. The toxin is believed to act directly on the autonomic nervous system to cause the illness, rather than on the gastrointestinal mucosa.

Related Pearl: Incidence and Prevalence

Incidence in Epidemiology:

  • Incidence is the number of new cases occurring in a defined population during a period of time.
  • Incidence = (Number of cases of a disease in a specified period of time/Population at risk during that time) x 1000
  • Incidence rate is expressed in person-time units, usually per 1000 per year.
  • It provides insight into the effectives of health services and programs.
  • Incidence rate of spells of sickness =  (Number of spells of sickness starting in the specified period/Mean number of people exposed to that risk in the specified time) x 1000
  • It is generally used for acute illnesses.
  • Special types of incidence rates:
    • Attack rate: It is used when there is a risk for a limited period of time.
    • Secondary attack rate: It is the number of exposed persons developing the disease within the range of incubation period following exposure to a primary case.
  • Incidence can be determined from cohort studies and longitudinal studies.

Prevalence in Epidemiology:

  • Prevalence is the proportion of all cases, old and new, of a particular disease at a given point in time or over a period of time in a given population.
  • It is a proportion, not a rate or ratio.
  • It can be determined from cross-sectional studies.
  • Types:
    • Point prevalence is the prevalence at a point in time. Usually, prevalence is point prevalence unless otherwise specified.
    • Period prevalence is the prevalence over a period of time.
  • Prevalence is always expressed in percentage.
  • Prevalence = (Number of all cases of a specified disease at a given point in time/Estimated population at the same point in time) x 100
  • It is useful to determine the magnitude of health problems.

Relationship between Incidence and Prevalence:

  • Prevalence depends upon incidence and duration.
  • Prevalence = Incidence x Mean Duration
  • Longer the duration of the disease, greater the prevalence.
  • In acute diseases,because of rapid recovery/death prevalence will be relatively lower than incidence.This is because in some diseases (eg. food poisoning), the disease is so short lived, there are no "old cases".
  • In chronic diseases like TB, prevalence will be higher than incidence.
  • If a new treatment for a disease is effective, incidence does not change but prevalence decreases as duration of disease decreases.
  • If treatment only prevents death but doesn’t cure the disease, it may cause a paradoxical increase in prevalence.

Related Pearl: Food Poisoning

>16 hrs incubation period

questions.text: A farmer while working in the field had a minor cut injury to the right feet and later developed rashes in the limbs. He now  presents to the OPD with a dry unproductive cough. Laboratory investigations show eosinophilia and patchy pneumonitis radiologically. All of the following parasites can be responsible for this condition except:
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Loeffler’s syndrome. Enterobius vermicularis does not cause Loeffler’s syndrome.

Development of rash after injury indicates skin penetration by larvae of the hookworms Ancylostoma duodenale and Necator americanus, and the roundworm Strongyloides stercoralis.

After penetrating the skin, larvae migrate within a day or two via the bloodstream into the lungs. When passing through the lungs, the disease may cause Loeffler syndrome.

Loeffler's syndrome is a disease in which eosinophils accumulate in the lung in response to a parasitic infection. It is associated with pneumonia characterized by dry cough, low-grade fever, wheezing, urticaria, and eosinophilia.

Parasites causing Loeffler’s syndrome:

  • Migrating larva of
    • Strongyloides stercoralis
    • Ancylostoma duodenale
    • Necator americanus
    • Ascaris lumbricoides (Eggs are ingested orally)
  • Echinococcus granulosus
  • Cryptosporidium parvum
  • Eggs of Paragonimus westermani
  • Entamoeba histolytica

questions.text: Identify the class of immunoglobulin​ shown in the image below.
questions.solution:
The above image shows a dimeric structure, characteristic of secretory IgA.

IgA immunoglobulin is the major antibody responsible for mucosal immunity. Its serum levels are usually low. It is predominantly present in the extravascular secretions. It is present in secretions such as milk, saliva, and tears, and in secretions of the respiratory, intestinal, and genital tracts.

When present in the serum, it exists as a monomer similar to IgG. However, when it is secreted, it exists as a dimer. The dimeric structure consists of two monomers, which are stabilized by two additional polypeptides:

  • J chain, which stabilizes the molecule.
  • Secretory component, which is incorporated into the IgA when transported through the epithelial cell.

Related Pearl: Properties of immunoglobulin classes

IgG:

  • Half-life- 23 days
  • Appears late, indicates chronic infection
  • It is the only maternal Ig to cross the placenta.
  • Has 4 subclasses.
  • Causes complement fixation, precipitation, and neutralization of toxins and virus.

IgM:

  • Half-life- 5 days
  • Has the highest molecular weight and is a pentamer.
  • Polysaccharides and lipids mainly stimulate IgM secretion.
  • Intravascular distribution.
  • Appears early, indicates recent infection.
  • Acts as surface immunoglobulin on the B cells.
  • It causes agglutination, hemolysis, and opsonization.

IgD:

  • Half-life- 2-8 days.
  • Acts as a surface immunoglobulin on the B cells.
  • Serves as recognition receptors for antigens.

IgE:

  • Half-life- 1-5 days
  • Causes type I hypersensitivity.
  • It is the only heat labile antibody.
  • Levels are raised in helminthic infections.

IgA:

  • Half-life- 6 days
  • It is of 2 types- Serum IgA and Secretory IgA 
  • Secretory IgA (A dimer) results in mucosal immunity.

questions.text: Which of the following Plasmodium spp. has the longest incubation period?
questions.solution:
Plasmodium malariae has the longest incubation period of 28 days.

The incubation period is the interval between the infective mosquito bite and the first appearance of clinical symptoms. The average incubation periods for Plasmodium species are:

  • P. vivax: 8-31 days (14 days)
  • P. falciparum: 8-14 days (12 days)
  • P. ovale: 8-31days (14 days)
  • P. malariae: 18-40 days (28 days)

Note: The pre-patent period is the interval between the entry of the parasites into the host and the time when they first become detectable in blood.

questions.text: Which of the following helminthic infections that is commonly transmitted by soil, is characterized by​ the egg in stool as shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
The given image shows the egg of Trichuris trichiura (whipworm).

Trichuris trichiura are barrel-shaped, thick-shelled, and have a pair of polar plugs at each end. They are commonly transmitted by soil. The eggs passed in the stool are unembryonated. Microscopic identification of the eggs in a stool specimen is diagnostic of whipworm infection.

Related Pearl: Eggs in parasitology

questions.text: A 35-year-old HIV positive​ patient presents with mucosal lesions in the mouth as shown in the image below. On microscopy, budding yeasts and pseudohyphae are seen. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis of the given clinical scenario is oral candidiasis.

Oral candidiasis or thrush is a patchy, pseudomembranous lesion that develops over the tongue, lips, gum or palate. It is composed of epithelial cells, yeasts, and pseudohyphae. The causative agent is usually Candida albicans.

It occurs in almost all individuals with AIDS. Other risk factors include hyperglycemia, cellular immunodeficiency, corticosteroids or antibiotics.

It is treated with topical nystatin or oral ketoconazole or fluconazole.

Option B: Hairy leukoplakia is a wart-like growth on the tongue, caused by Epstein Barr virus. It is commonly seen as a white lesion on the lateral side of the tongue.

Option C: Lichen planus is a pruritic disease characterized by papules commonly seen over the flexor surfaces and trunk. Oral and vulvovaginal lesions may also occur. Oral lesions appear as lacy, white, and raised lesions.

Option D: Diphtheria is characterized by the presence of a grey pseudomembrane covering the tonsils and pharynx. It is caused by Corynebacterium diphtheriae.

Related Pearl: Classification of fungus based on morphology

Fungi are classified into 4 types based on their morphology:

  • Yeast
  • Yeast-like
  • Molds
  • Dimorphic fungi

Yeast:

  • Unicellular fungi
  • Reproduces by budding
  • Oval to round forms
  • Example: Cryptococcus, Saccharomyces.

 

Yeast like:

  • Unicellular fungi
  • Reproduces by budding or binary fission
  • Spherical or oval forms
  • Pseudohyphae may be seen.
  • Example: Candida, Malassezia furfur.

 

Molds/filamentous fungi:

  • Have hyphae which may be septate or aseptate
  • Aseptate or coenocytic hyphae – Rhizopus, mucor, Lichtheimia.
  • Septate hyphae – Penicillium, Dermatophytes, Aspergillus, fusarium.

 

Dimorphic fungi

  • Filamentous forms in the culture at 220C – 250C and in the environment.
  • Yeast form in the culture at 370C and in tissues.
  • Examples – Histoplasma capsulatum, Blastomyces dermatitidis, Coccidioides immitis, Paracoccidioides brasiliensis, Talaromyces marneffei, Sporothrix schenckii.

questions.text: The following skin lesions are a side effect of which anticancer drug?
questions.solution:
The given image shows flagellate dermatitis. It is caused by bleomycin.

Flagellate dermatitis starts as bands of pruritic, flagellate, erythema over the trunk and extremities a few hours to 6 months after administration. The rash heals with persistent flagellate hyperpigmentation.No treatment is necessary since the lesions usually disappear when the administration of bleomycin is stopped.

Other agents causing flagellate dermatitis:

  • Docetaxel
  • Bendamustine
  • Peplomycin

questions.text: Which of the following about clinical trials is incorrect?

choices.text: Phase I – Access efficacy and dosage
Phase II – In most cases drugs are first time introduced in patients

questions.solution:
Phase I trial is done to access safety and tolerability. It is conducted mostly on healthy volunteers and rarely on patients with advanced or rare diseases.

questions.text: An elderly chronic smoker is diagnosed with ischemic heart disease and is started on propranolol. After some days, he is brought to the emergency department with a history of difficulty in breathing which he says gets worsened after taking propranolol. The mechanism that is mainly responsible for worsening his breathing difficulty is
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, the symptoms of respiratory difficulty in the patient have worsened after the intake of propranolol. The mechanism that is mainly responsible for worsening his breathing is β2 blockade. Propranolol is a non-selective beta-blocker. It blocks the β2 receptors in bronchial smooth muscle and prevents bronchodilation. Therefore, it should not be given to patients who have asthma and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease.

Other important side effects of beta-blockers are:

  • Cardiovascular system- 
    • Beta blockade decreases myocardial contractility. Therefore, it can exacerbate decompensated heart failure.
    • Decreased heart rate- Bradycardia, In patients with heart block it can cause fatal bradyarrhythmias
    • Abrupt discontinuation of β receptor antagonists after long-term treatment can exacerbate angina
  • Respiratory system- bronchospasm due to blockade of β2 receptors in the bronchial smooth muscles.
  • Central nervous system- fatigue, sleep disturbances, and depression.
  • Exacerbation of peripheral artery disease occurs due to the blockade of β2 receptors in the vascular smooth muscles.
  • It can slow the recovery from insulin-induced hypoglycemia as they inhibit catecholamine-mediated glycogenolysis.
  • This class of drugs is also known to mask the hypoglycemia symptoms in diabetic patients. The symptoms of hypoglycemia which are mediated by the adrenaline release will be masked as beta-blockers will not allow adrenaline to react and interact with its beta 1 receptor.  
  • Hyperkalemia- blockade of β2 receptors prevents the entry of extracellular potassium into the cells.
  • Sexual dysfunction in males
  • They can also alter the serum triglyceride and HDL-cholesterol concentrations. Beta-blockers such as atenolol, metoprolol, and propranolol increase the levels of triglycerides and decrease the levels of high-density lipoprotein (HDL) cholesterol. Other beta-blockers like labetalol, pindolol, and acebutolol do not have any effect on lipid levels.

Autonomic innervation of the lung.

Relaxation of the tracheal and bronchial smooth muscles is brought by β2 receptors. Contraction is by the M2 and M3 cholinergic receptors. Therefore, important drugs that used for bronchodilation are 

  • β2 selective agonists like salbutamol, terbutaline, salmeterol, formoterol, etc,
  • Antimuscarinic agents like ipratropium bromide, tiotropium, aclidinium, and umeclidinium.

Propranolol is a non-selective beta-blocker. It acts equal affinity to both β1 and β2 receptors. It does not have intrinsic sympathomimetic activity and does not block α receptors.

Important adverse effects of propranolol are:

Cardiovascular system- It can cause or exacerbate heart failure in patients with compensated heart failure, acute myocardial infarction, or cardiomegaly. In patients with partial or complete AV conduction defects, β antagonists may cause life-threatening bradyarrhythmias. Sudden discontinuation of beta-blockers after prolonged use can exacerbate angina and may increase the risk of sudden death.

Respiratory system- It blocks the β2 receptors in bronchial smooth muscle and can cause bronchospasm.

Nervous system- It causes fatigue, sleep disturbances (including insomnia and nightmares), and depression.

Metabolism- It delays the recovery from insulin-induced hypoglycemia.

Overdosage may lead to hypotension, bradycardia, prolonged AV conduction, and widened QRS complexes, seizures, depression, hypoglycemia, and bronchospasm.

Related Pearl: Cardioselective beta blockers: Mnemonic

Cardioselective Beta blockers Act At Nothing But Myocardium Exclusively.

  • C: Celiprolol ( III )
  • B: Bisoprolol
  • A: Acebutolol
  • A: Atenolol
  • N: Nebivolol ( III )
  • B: Betaxolol ( III )
  • M: Metoprolol
  • E: Esmolol

( III ) - Third generation beta blockers. All the others are second generation beta blockers

questions.text: Select a correct and rational drug prescription for the given hypertensive patients

choices.text: A 28 year old male with gout - Chlorthalidone
A 36 year old male with migraine - Propanolol
A multigravida 16 weeks of gestation with known case of hypertension - Captopril
A 54 year old lady with heart failure on digoxin - Verapamil

questions.solution:
Among the given options, Propanolol in a case of migraine is a rational prescription as it might be useful in preventing migraine attacks.
 
Other options:
Chlorthalidone (thiazide diuretics) should be avoided in a case of gout because of hyperuricemia induced by thiazides.
Captopril (ACE inhibitor) should be avoided in pregnancy because of its known teratogenic effect
Verapamil (non-dihydropyridine CCBs) should be avoided in HF due to the worsening of HF or along with statin or digoxin due to decreased metabolism and toxicity.
 
Conditions associated with hypertension
First choice drugs for hypertension
Diabetes
Chronic kidney disease with proteinuria
Inhibitors of renin-angiotensin system.
Angina
Beta-blockers or calcium channel blockers
Heart failure
ACE inhibitors and alpha+beta blockers such as carvedilol
Benign prostatic hyperplasia
α1 Blockers
Pregnancy
Labetalol
Atrial fibrillation
Diltiazem and verapamil

questions.text: Which of the following is not seen with the usage of liraglutide in diabetic patients?

choices.text: Causes weight gain when used over a year
Reduces the risk of cardiovascular death
It is better than exenatide in reducing HbA1C
Used with both oral hypoglycemics and basal insulin

questions.solution:
Liraglutide causes weight loss and improves glycemic control.

Also, it reduces the risk of cardiovascular death. It is better than exenatide in reducing HbA1C.

It is a soluble fatty acid-acylated GLP-1 analog. The half-life is approximately 12 hours, permitting once-daily dosing. It is approved in patients with type 2 diabetes who achieve inadequate control with diet and exercise and are receiving concurrent treatment with metformin, sulfonylureas, or thiazolidinediones.

It reduces post-meal hyperglycemia by

  • Increasing glucose-mediated insulin release
  • Lowering glucagon levels
  • Slowing gastric emptying
  • Decreasing appetite

It is used in type 2 DM and is the only GLP-1 receptor agonist used in obesity.

NOTE:

GLP-1 analogs, pramlintide, SGLT-2 inhibitors, and metformin* cause weight loss.

DPP-4 inhibitors and alpha-glucosidase inhibitors are weight neutral drugs.

Sulfonylureas and insulin promote weight gain.

questions.text: A patient with CKD underwent nephrectomy. Which of the following can be administered as post-op analgesic in this patient?
questions.solution:
Acetaminophen can be given as an analgesic for the patient as it is the least nephrotoxic among the given options.

Analgesia in CKD patients:

Acetaminophen is considered a safer non-narcotic analgesic in CKD patients. For more severe pains opioid analgesics like tramadol or fentanyl are used. 

Even though acetaminophen is considered safe, with chronic high dosage it can also become nephrotoxic.

NSAIDs like naproxen, indomethacin, diclofenac, etc are not in CKD patients because of their direct nephrotoxic effects. In healthy normal individuals, NSAIDs have little effect on renal function and blood pressure. But in conditions where the regulatory systems are impaired as hypovolemia, congestive heart failure, hepatic cirrhosis, chronic kidney disease, or other conditions where the renin-angiotensin system is activated, renal function by the formation of prostaglandins are very important.

NSAIDs cause impairment of prostaglandin-induced inhibition of chlorine reabsorption and antidiuretic hormone action. This will cause salt and water retention. It also inhibits COX-2 derived prostaglandins which regulate the renal medullary blood flow and would lead to a rise in blood pressure, increased cardiovascular thrombotic events, and cardiac failure. It can also cause electrolyte abnormalities like hyponatremia and hyperkalemia.

questions.text: A 23-year-old female diagnosed with hepatitis A complained of persistent nausea. An antiemetic was given intravenously three times a day. After two days, the patient felt painful arching of neck and upwards rolling of eyes. The antiemetic is most likely to be
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario depicted is suggestive of dystonia, which is an adverse effect observed due to D2 receptor antagonism of metoclopramide. 

Metoclopramide is an antiemetic agent which mainly acts by D2 receptor antagonism, 5HT4 receptor agonism and 5HT3 receptor antagonism. It can be used both as a prokinetic agent and antiemetic.

Other options:

  • Ondansetron and Granisetron mainly act by 5HT3 antagonism. This class of drugs are most effective in treating chemotherapy induced vomiting.
  • Nabilone is a synthetic cannabinoid and acts by stimulating the CB1 subtype of cannabinoid receptors. It can lead to marijuana-like highs with euphoria, somnolence, detachment, dizziness, anxiety, nervousness, panic attack, etc. It is used to prevent chemotherapy induced vomiting when other antiemetics have failed.

questions.text: Which of the following accurately represents the action of glucocorticoids on the function of osteoblasts and osteoclasts?
questions.solution:
Glucocorticoids inhibit osteoblasts and stimulate osteoclasts resulting in the development of osteoporosis.

Other causes of osteoporosis by corticosteroids:

  • Inhibition of gonadal steroidal hormones
  • Reduced gastrointestinal absorption of calcium
  • The secondary effect of decreased calcium absorption: increased parathyroid hormone leading to further resorption

The ribs and the vertebrae are the most frequent sites of fracture

questions.text: In a patient with an acute exacerbation of asthma with severely compromised lung function who is not responsive to nebulized beta 2 agonists, which of the following is the steroid of choice for systemic use?
questions.solution:
Hydrocortisone is the steroid of choice in acute exacerbation of asthma (especially when the lung function is <30% predicted and there is no improvement with nebulized β2 agonist). It has the most rapid onset (5–6 hours after administration), compared to 8 hours with prednisolone.

It is given at a dose of 4 mg/kg initially, followed by a maintenance dose of 3 mg/kg every 6 hours. Intravenous therapy is usually given until a satisfactory response is obtained, and then it is replaced with oral prednisolone.

Mechanism of action of Corticosteroids in an acute asthma attack:

  • Increases responsiveness to Beta-2 agonists
  • Decreases mucous secretion
  • Decreases inflammatory cell response.

Steroids increase the transcription of beta 2 receptor genes and hence increases responsiveness to beta-2 agonists. Beta-2 agonists, on the other hand, increase the effect of steroids by enhancing the action of glucocorticoid receptors.

Theophylline increases the effects of steroids by activating enzyme histone deacetylase which is the target for steroids as well.

questions.text: What is the primary agent in the treatment of trigeminal neuralgia?
questions.solution:
Carbamazepine is the primary agent for the treatment of trigeminal neuralgia. If carbamazepine is not effective then second-line agents like lamotrigine and phenytoin are used. 

Trigeminal neuralgia:

  • More common in females over 50 years
  • Characterized by unilateral lancinating facial pain, most commonly involving the second and/or third divisions of the trigeminal nerve territory
  • Bilateral or early onset is associated with multiple sclerosis
  • Unilateral trigeminal nerve compresion can be due to superior cerebellar artey.
  • Pain is repetitive, severe, and very brief.
  • This occurs spontaneously or triggered by touch, a cold wind or eating.
  • Physical signs are usually absent, although the spasms may make the patient wince and sit silently (tic douloureux).
  • No objective signs of sensory loss.
  • Drug of choice-carbamazepine

questions.text: The graph below shows the relationship between the log[Dose] and the response of three drugs A, B, and C. Which of the following options is true in regards to the drugs' efficacy?
questions.solution:
In the log dose-response curve, the perpendicular height represents the drug efficacy.

Therefore, Drug C has the least efficacy. Both Drug A and Drug B have the highest efficacy that is the maximum effect produced by the drug. Thus, in the above image, the efficacy is Drug A = Drug B > Drug C.

Efficacy:

  • It is defined as the maximum effect produced by the drug.
  • It reflects the capacity of the drug to activate a receptor and produce the response.
  • In the log dose-response curve, the perpendicular height represents the drug efficacy. Thus, in the above image, the efficacy is Drug A = Drug B > Drug C.

Potency:

  • It is defined as the amount of drug needed to produce a given response. 
  • A highly potent drug evokes a given response at low concentrations and vice-versa.
  • The more the curve is on the left in a log dose-response curve (DRC), the greater is its potency. Thus, in the above image, Drug A is more potent. The potency is Drug A >Drug B> Drug C.(option B)

questions.text: Which of the following can be prescribed in case of an open angle glaucoma with bronchial asthma?
questions.solution:
Latanoprost can be given in a case of open-angle glaucoma with bronchial asthma.

Latanoprost is a PGF2α analog and it is not associated with systemic side effects like bronchospasm and hence can be given for asthmatic patients. Prostaglandin analogs are the first choice drugs for open-angle glaucoma.

Mechanism of action: It reduces intraocular pressure by altering the ciliary muscle tension and improving the outflow of the aqueous humor.

Advantages of latanoprost:

  • Good efficacy
  • Once-daily application
  • Absence of systemic side effects

Disadvantage: High cost

Adverse effects:

  • Blurring of vision
  • Iris pigmentation
  • Thickening and darkening of eyelashes
  • Macular edema can occur especially in aphakic patients.

Other options:

Timolol: It is a non-selective beta-blocker used topically in glaucoma. It is associated with systemic effects by absorption through the nasolacrimal duct and can cause life-threatening bronchospasm in asthmatics and COPD patients. Hence they are not given in asthmatic patients.

Gemeprost: It is a PGE1 analog used for the termination of early preganacy.

Mannitol infusion: It is given for acute congestive glaucoma and not for open-angle glaucoma. It causes decongestion of the eye by its osmotic action.

Related Pearl: Antiglaucoma drugs: Mechanism of lowering intraocular pressure (IOP) at a glance

Drugs that increase trabecular outflow

  • Miotics (e.g., pilocarpine)
  • Epinephrine, dipivefrine
  • Bimatoprost

Drugs that increase uveoscleral outflow

  • Prostaglandins (latanoprost)
  • Epinephrine, dipivefrine
  • Brimonidine
  • Apraclonidine

Drugs that decrease aqueous production

  • Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors (e.g., acetazolamide, dorzolamide)
  • Alpha receptor stimulators in ciliary process (e.g., epinephrine, dipivefrine, clonidine, brimonidine, apraclonidine)
  • Beta-blockers

Hyperosmotic agents - (e.g., glycerol, mannitol, urea)

questions.text: A young woman who is diagnosed with drug-sensitive tuberculosis is started with isoniazid, rifampicin, ethambutol, and pyrazinamide. During the follow up it is found that she has light chain proteinuria and orange coloured urine. Which of the drugs could have been the cause?
questions.solution:
Light chain proteinuria and orange coloured urine is caused by rifampicin.

Rifampicin inhibits bacterial DNA-dependent RNA polymerase and thereby inhibits RNA synthesis. resistance to this drug results from the mutation of rpoB gene.

It is bactericidal in nature and can kill organisms that are present intracellularly or in abscesses and cavities.

It can be used against the infections of mycobacterium, meningococcus, Hemophilus influenzae, etc.

Important adverse effects of rifampicin are

  • Flu-like symptoms
  • Imparts orange color to urine, sweat, and tears.
  • Light chain proteinuria
  • Hepatitis
  • Cholestatic jaundice
  • Rashes
  • Thrombocytopenia
  • Nephritis

It induces most cytochrome P450 isoforms and increases the elimination of methadone, anticoagulants, cyclosporine, some anticonvulsants, protease inhibitors, some nonnucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitors or integrase inhibitors, contraceptives, etc.

Other options

Option A- Isoniazid inhibits mycolic acid synthesis by inhibiting the enzyme beta-ketoacyl carrier protein synthetase. Important side effects of this drug are:

  • Fever, skin rashes
  • Drug-induced lupus
  • Isoniazid induced hepatitis
  • Peripheral neuropathy occurs as a result of pyridoxine deficiency. Isoniazid promotes pyridoxine excretion. It is likely to be seen in slow acetylators.

Option B- Pyrazinamide is converted to pyrazinoic acid. This disrupts the mycobacterial cell membrane metabolism and transport functions. Important side effects of this drug are:

  • Hepatotoxicity
  • Nausea, vomiting
  • Fever
  • Photosensitivity 
  • Hyperuricemia

Option C- Ethambutol inhibits mycobacterial cell wall synthesis by inhibiting mycobacterial arabinosyl transferases. An important side effect of this drugs is retrobulbar neuritis, resulting in loss of visual acuity and red-green color blindness.

Related Pearl: Key points on the first line drugs used in the treatment of TB

Drugs Isoniazid Rifamycins Pyrazinamide Ethambutol
Mechanism of action Blocks mycolic acid synthesis. Inhibition of RNA polymerase, leading to the inhibition of RNA synthesis. Inhibition of fatty acid synthase-I, leading to the inhibition of the cell membrane. Inhibition of arabinosyl transferase, leading to a reduction in arabinogalactan needed for the cell wall.
Unique side effects

Shoulder hand syndrome and CNS side effects.

 Orange urine, sweat, and tears. Flu-like symptoms with intermittent dosing.

The most hepatotoxic drug. It also causes hyperuricemia.

Optic neuritis and hence, not preferred in children.
Mechanism of resistance

Kat G mutation- the most severe form of resistance.

Inh a gene overexpression-  confers cross-resistance with ethionamide.

Mutation in rpoB- the gene coding for the β subunit of RNA polymerase.

 Mutation of the Pnca gene.

Mutations in the embB gene.

Related Pearl: ATT Regimen -TB Patients

As per the latest recommendations from National Tuberculosis Elimination Programme (NTEP), treatment of TB is now based primarily on drug susceptibility testing. This is irrespective of new cases, previously treated cases or recurrent TB cases. 
All cases of TB are treated with Drug Sensitive TB Regimen, as long as the patient is sensitive to isoniazid and rifampicin. (No classification into category I or II)

Type of TB Case Intensive Phase Continuation Phase
New and previously treated cases (H and R sensitive) 2 H R Z E 4 H R E

Classification based on drug resistance

  • Mono-resistant (MR): A TB patient, who is resistant to one 1st line anti-TB drug only.
  • Poly-Drug Resistant (PDR): A TB patient, who is resistant to more than one 1st line anti-TB drug, other than Rifampicin. 
  • Rifampicin Resistant (RR): A TB patient, who is resistant to rifampicin with or without resistance to other drugs. Patients, who have rifampicin resistance, should be managed as if they are an MDR TB case.
  • Multi Drug Resistant (MDR): A TB patient, who is resistant to both isoniazid and rifampicin.
  • Extensively Drug Resistant (XDR): A MDR TB patient who is additionally resistant to a fluoroquinolone (ofloxacin, levofloxacin, or moxifloxacin) and a second-line injectable anti TB drug (kanamycin, amikacin, or capreomycin).

Standard DR TB regimen

Regimen class Drugs Comments
H mono-resistant/ poly-drug resistant TB regimen Lfx R E Z for 6 months
  • 6 months long
  • Oral drugs only
Shorter MDR TB regimen

Intensive Phase:

Mfx Km/Am Eto Cfz Z H E for 4-6 months

Continuation phase:

Mfx Cfz Z E for 5 months
  • 9-11 months long
  • Injectables used in intensive phase.
Longer MDR TB regimen Bdq(6 months) Lfx Lzd Cfz Cs for 18-20 months
  • 18-20 months long
  • Oral drugs only
  • This regimen is used for XDR TB patients for 20 months.

questions.text: You are working as a medical officer in a PHC. One day your friend brought his dead father to the hospital and told you that he died of myocardial infarction. He pressures you to issue the death certificate and you oblige filling up myocardial infarction as the cause of death. Later there were accusations about this death and it was found that this person died of organophosphorus poisoning. You could be tried in court under IPC section _________
questions.solution:
The doctor could be tried under IPC section 197. IPC section 197 deals with issuing or signing false certificates.

IPC section 46 denotes the death of the human being, unless the contrary appears from the context. In simple words, the word “death” denotes the death of a human being unless the context suggests otherwise.

IPC section 269 denotes negligent act likely to spread infection of disease dangerous to life.

IPC section 204 denotes destruction of document to prevent its production as evidence.

questions.text: During the examination of a victim of assault, you notice a wound with ragged, irregular, and uneven margins with tears diverging at an angle from the end of the main wound and typical ‘swallow tails’. Bleeding from this wound is not significant and shows crushed blood vessels and hair bulbs. You would document this wound as a/an ___________________
questions.solution:
The characteristics described are consistent with that of a lacerated wound

The characteristics of a lacerated wound:

The margins are ragged, irregular, and uneven. Tearing at the ends of a laceration, at angles diverging from the main one itself are called swallow tails.

The edges of the laceration may indicate a direction, in which the blow or force was applied. Depth of the wound shows bridges of irregularly torn fibrous tissue, blood vessels, and nerves and can be soiled by mud, sand, glass, brick particles, vegetation, machine oils, hair, or fibers. These materials embedded in the wound are of great medicolegal value.

Lacerated wounds do not bleed much as the vessels are crushed and torn, thus facilitating hemostasis. The exception to this is injuries to the scalp, where temporal arteries may bleed freely as they are firmly bound and unable to contract. Lacerations over the hairy areas will show hair bulbs crushed and buried into the depth of the wound. Because of the crushing and tearing nature of the production of lacerations, there can be associated abrasion or bruising.

 Swallow tail in a Lacerated wound

 

Fishtails - These may be seen in stab wounds where the skin splits at the corner. 

The given image shows a chop wound.

Chop wounds are so-called because of the action in which they are produced. Depending on the type of instrument, they may resemble an incised or a lacerated wound. The shape of the wound may give clues to the type of weapon. For example, in the given image, the wound resembles an injury produced by a sharp axe. Such wounds may be inflicted with homicidal intent on the skull/scalp. Chop wounds are usually deep gaping wounds caused by a blow with the sharp cutting edge of a fairly heavy weapon like an axe, sword, hatchet etc

questions.text: The least common fingerprint pattern is _____________.
questions.solution:
Composite type (1-2%) is the least common fingerprint pattern.

Patterns of fingerprints:

  • Loops - Most common type (60-70%)
  • Whorl - (25-30%)
  • Arch - (6-7%) They may be plain, tented, or exceptional. 
  • Composite forms (1 – 2%) - least common

The study of ridge patterns in the skin is Dactylography/ Galton-Henry system/ Dermatoglyphics. Fingerprints are the impressions of patterns produced by the papillary or epidermal ridges present on the fingertips.

Classification of fingerprints into different patterns is based on delta and core formation. Delta is a triangular arrangement formed where three separate ridge line flows come together. The core is the centermost portion of a ridge flow pattern. 

The number of delta and core for each pattern is given below.

Pattern  Delta  Core
Loop 1 1
Plain arch 0 0
Tented arch 1 delta at the base of the upthrust 0
Whorl 2 1

The image given below shows the delta and core in the different fingerprint patterns. For each type, the position of the core is marked with a green circle, and the delta is marked with a blue triangle.

questions.text: A dead body was found in an abandoned state in a forest. The postmortem changes that were seen in the body is given in the figure. These changes are seen in:
questions.solution:
The image shows marbling which is seen in putrefaction. Due to the bacterial action, there is the formation of the Sulf-methemoglobin which causes greenish-brown or purplish-red discolouration of superficial veins.

Modifications of putrefaction are:

Adipocere - It forms under warm and humid weather due to hydrolysis of lipids. It has a whitish or yellowish appearance and has a distinctive offensive or sweetish smell.

Mummification - It occurs in the absence of moisture in the air and continuous action of dry, warm air. The natural appearances and general features of the body are preserved.

Below is the image of a mummified body:

questions.text: Rigor mortis occurs first in:
questions.solution:
Rigor mortis occurs first in the myocardium.

The order of appearance of rigor mortis: Left chamber of heart is affected first. Other muscles are affected in the given order:

  1. Involuntary muscles: Heart
  2. Eyelids
  3. Neck and lower jaw
  4. Face
  5. Chest
  6. Upper extremities
  7. Abdomen
  8. Legs
  9. Fingers and toes

Note- Rigor mortis first occurs in the myocardium but is first seen in eyelids. Here the question is first occurs in and the answer is myocardium.

questions.text: The following image shows:
questions.solution:
The above image is of a joule burn. It is formed at the point of contact with electricity. It is more popularly referred to as 'electrical burns' or 'electrical Marks.' Electrical burns may not always be evident, even in cases of fatal electrocutions as it is dependent on a number of factors like contact area, duration, presence of intervening moisture etc. 

Soot-soiling occurs from the person holding a shotgun barrel.

  • In tight flesh contact wounds, soot soiling and muzzle marks are uncommon. If there is loose contact or clothes are interposed, there may be soiling or muzzle marks.
  • In a case involving a close-range shotgun injury, if a victim catches the barrel of the gun, there may be soot-soling of the hands.

Frost Bite:

Above is the image of frostbite. It occurs when the body is exposed to cold temperatures.

Scalding:

Scalds are due to exposure to wet heat like hot water or steam.

questions.text: Letulles technique is an autopsy technique characterised by ________

choices.text: Removal of organs one by one

questions.solution:
Letulle's technique is characterized by en masse removal of organs. It means thoracic, cervical, abdominal, and pelvic organs are removed as one big organ block.

Related Pearl: Paraphilic disorders

DSM-5 includes eight specific paraphilic disorders:

years of age or younger

questions.text: A 5-year-old child with a ​history of perianal pain is brought to the OPD. On subjecting the specimen from the perianal region to a test, it produces yellow rhombic crystals of spermine picrate. What is the test done?
questions.solution:
The test done in the scenario is Barberio test. It is used to detect seminal fluid.

When saturated aqueous or alcoholic solution of picric acid is added to the spermatic fluid, yellow needle-shaped rhombic crystals of spermine picrate are produced.

Other options: 

Option B: Florence test: 

  • The suspected seminal stain is extracted with 10% hydrochloric acid and a drop of it is placed over a slide.
  • A coverslip is placed over it and a drop of Florence solution (potassium iodide, iodine, and water) is made to run under the coverslip.
  • If semen is present, dark brown rhombic or needle-shaped crystals of choline iodide appear immediately.

Option C: Takayama test (Haemochromogen crystal test): 

  • The test is used to detect suspected bloodstains. Small piece of suspected material is added on a glass slide.
  • Then, 2-3 drops of Takayama reagent is added and covered with a coverslip.
  • If it is a bloodstain, pink feathery crystals of hemochromogen or reduced alkaline haematin appear in a few minutes.

Option D: Teichmann test (Haemin Crystal Test): 

  • The test is used to detect suspected bloodstains.
  • Small piece of suspected material is placed on a glass slide. Then, 2-3 drops of glacial acetic acid and a small crystal of sodium chloride are added to the glass slide and covered with a coverslip. The slide is then heated.
  • If bloodstain is present, faint yellowish-red to brownish-black rhombic crystals of haemin or haematin chloride appear.
  • When hydrogen peroxide is added, the haematin crystals give bubbles of gas.

Related Pearl: Tests to detect seminal and blood stains

Tests for seminal stains

  • Barberio's test
  • Florence test
  • Acid phosphatase test
  • Creatine phosphokinase test
  • Immunological test to detect Prostate Specific Antigen

Tests for blood stains  

  • Benzidine test
  • Phenophthalein (Kastle Meyer) test
  • Takayama hemochromogen crystal test
  • Teichmann’s hemin crystal test
  • Spectroscopic test

questions.text: In alleged history of gunshot injury, there is burning, blackening, tattooing around the wound. The injury is:
questions.solution:
Based on the ballistics, the gunshot injury is close shot entry wound.

  • The main objective of study of a firearm wound (Ballistics) is to establish the range and direction of firing, the ultimate purpose is to determine the weapon used for firing.
  • Firearm wounds are fundamentally of two mains types: wounds of entry and wound of exit. The wound of entry is the wound through which the bullet or pellets enter the body, and the wound of exit is the wound through which the bullet emerges out of the body.
  • To determine the Range of firing, following parameters are used:
    • Entry wound size and shape
    • Blast effect – Muzzle end imprint and edge eversion
    • Blackening, Tattooing, Singeing of hair, Abrasion collar and Grease collar
  • In the above options, Hair should be preserved in order to determine the range of firing which can be examined for carbonisation/dessication in close range, also from lead deposition around the wound to assess range of firing.

questions.text: A man was stuck inside a building that caught fire. He died of suffocation due to smoke. Which of the following postmortem changes is likely to be seen?
questions.solution:
The person died of suffocation due to smoke. This indicates carbon monoxide (CO) poisoning which will cause cherry red postmortem hypostasis.

Victims of smoke inhalation are affected by carbon monoxide poisoning. Carbon monoxide has a higher affinity to haemoglobin as compared to oxygen and hence the amount of haemoglobin available for oxygen transport is markedly reduced. It can cause anaemic hypoxia. The binding of CO to haemoglobin results in cherry red discolouration.

Other options:

Option A- Mummification requires high temperature and strong air currents. As there were no air currents in this situation, mummification is unlikely.

Option B- Pugilistic attitude is seen when muscle proteins are coagulated at high temperatures. Since this person did not die of burn injuries, a pugilistic attitude will not be seen.

Option D- Rigor mortis is not delayed. On the contrary, it may have rapid onset because of heat.

questions.text: A 35-year-old soccer coach presents with pain in the left ear. He gives a history of trauma to the same ear a few days back and complains of pain and redness for the past week. On examination, his left ear feels warm, swollen, slightly tender to touch and is firm.  What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a red and stiff pinna. The clinical vignette along with the image is suggestive of perichondritis.

Aetiology:

  • MC cause is trauma either iatrogenic (surgical incision) or non iatrogenic (laceration, haematoma). It can be due to extension of infection from diffuse otitis externa or furuncle of meatus.
  • MC organism – Pseudomonas aeruginosa

Symptoms:

  • Initially, the pinna is red, hot, painful and stiff.
  • In the later stages, an abscess may form between the cartilage and perichondrium with necrosis of cartilage as the cartilage survives only on the blood supply from its perichondrium.

Treatment:

  • Treatment in the early stages consists of systemic antibiotics and the local application of 4% aluminium acetate compresses.
  • When an abscess has formed, it must be drained promptly and the culture and sensitivity of the pus obtained. The incision is made in the natural fold and devitalized cartilage is removed.
  • Some prefer to place a catheter in the abscess and administer a continuous drip of antibiotics, selected by culture and sensitivity for 7–10 days.

 

The above image shows cauliflower ear (Option -A) also known as perichondrial hematoma or wrestler's ear, is a deformity of the ear caused by trauma.

Treatment is the aspiration of the haematoma under strict aseptic precautions and a pressure dressing, carefully packing all concavities of the auricle to prevent reaccumulation. Aspiration may need to be repeated. When aspiration fails, incision and drainage should be done and pressure applied by dental rolls tied with through and through sutures. All cases should receive prophylactic antibiotics.

 

The above image shows chondrodermatitis chronica helicis (Option-C) which is a small, nodular, tender, chronic inflammatory lesion occurring on the helix of the ear. Treatment is excision of the nodule with its skin and cartilage.

 

The above image shows otitis externa (Option-D) also called swimmer's ear. It is the inflammation of the ear canal. Treatment includes aural toilet, antibiotics, analgesics and medicated wicks.

questions.text: Rinne’s test done on a patient shows that air conduction is better than bone conduction in both ears. Weber's test lateralises to the left ear. The diagnosis is?

choices.text: Conductive hearing loss in the right ear
Conductive hearing loss in the left ear
Sensorineural hearing loss in the right ear
Sensorineural hearing loss in the left ear

questions.solution:
When Weber’s test is lateralised to left ear and the Rinne’s test is normal, then there is sensorineural hearing loss in the right ear.

In Weber test, a vibrating tuning fork is placed in the middle of the forehead or the vertex and the patient is asked in which ear the sound is heard. Normally, it is heard equally in both ears.

It is lateralized to the worse ear in conductive deafness and to the better ear in sensorineural deafness.

questions.text: An elderly diabetic female who was treated with steroids and remdevisir for COVID now presented with a black, foul-smelling discharge from the nose. On examination, blackish necrotic mass filling the nasal cavity and eroding the septum and hard palate. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Mucormycosis.

Mucormycosis is a non-contagious fungal disease most commonly caused by Rhizopus oryzae that is acquired through the inhalation of fungal spores from air. It may occur during COVID infection or after a few weeks (usually around the 3rd week) of recovery from it. Reasons for increase in mucormycosis cases in COVID patients are:

  • Uncontrolled hyperglycemia due to any reason. COVID per se has a tendency to worsen diabetes and also precipitate diabetes in previously normal individuals. 
  • Misuse and irrational use of steroids. Steroid overuse can cause new-onset diabetes.
  • Leucopenia associated with COVID
  • Prolonged ICU stay, unhygienic humidifiers, and irrational use of broad-spectrum antibiotics.
  • Pre-existing comorbidities such as hematological malignancies, use of immunosuppressants, and solid organ transplantation.

A high index of suspicion is required for the early diagnosis of mucormycosis. Checklist of sentinel signs/ symptoms of mucormycosis to be monitored in patients admitted with COVID-19 are:

  1. Relatively early disease (Nose and sinuses):
    • Headache and nasal obstruction (especially if severe or persistent and not responding to medications)
    • Nasal crusting, brownish or blood-tinged nasal discharge
    • Facial pain, pain over sinuses
    • Paraesthesia/ loss of sensation over half of the face
    • Discoloration of the skin or localized facial puffiness
    • Loosening of teeth, discoloration, ulceration, or eschar over the palate
  2. Moderately advanced disease (Eye/orbital involvement):
    • Eye swelling or redness, eye pain
    • Double vision, drooping of the eyelid, blurring, and loss of vision.
  3. Very advanced disease (Intracranial involvement):
    • Involvement of cranial nerves II-VI suggestive of cavernous sinus thrombosis
    • Signs of MCA thrombosis 

Diagnosis:

  • KOH mount and microscopy
  • Histopathology of debrided tissue shows presence of ribbon-like aseptate hyphae (5-15 µ thick) branching at right angles.
  • Culture can be done but treatment should be started on clinical suspicion.
  • CT of sinuses, CT chest for suspected pulmonary involvement ( presence of more than 10 nodules, reverse halo sign are highly suggestive of mucor), and MRI brain to look for the extent of intracranial involvement.

Management:

  • Treatment of co-morbid illness and strict glycemic control.
  • Anti-fungal therapy started early on high clinical suspicion even prior to microbiological confirmation can reduce mortality. Treatment involves a combination of surgical debridement and antifungal therapy.
  • Liposomal Amphotericin B (5-10mg/kg) is the drug of choice and has to be continued for 3-6 weeks. It should be diluted in 5% dextrose and is incompatible with normal saline and Ringer lactate. Step-down therapy to be done with oral posaconazole or isavuconazole. Renal function must be monitored during the entire treatment period.
  • Early surgical debridement after stabilization of systemic illness and ensuring facilities for post-surgical care and ventilation.

Guidelines for discharge of COVID patients (As per Revised discharge policy for COVID by MoHFW):

  1. Mild/ very mild/ pre-symptomatic cases: discharged after 10 days of symptom onset and no fever for 3 days. There will be no need for testing prior to discharge. At the time of discharge, advise patient to isolate himself at home and self-monitor their health for next 7 days.
  2. Moderate cases admitted to Dedicated COVID Health Centre (Oxygen beds): 
    • Patients whose symptoms resolve within 3 days and maintains SpO2 >95% for the next 4 days without oxygen support, can be discharged after 10 days of symptom onset. There will be no need for testing prior to discharge. At the time of discharge, advise patient to isolate himself at home and self-monitor their health for next 7 days.
    • Patients whose fever does not resolve within 3 days and demand of oxygen therapy continues should be discharged only after resolution of clinical symptoms and able to maintain oxygen saturation for 3 consecutive days.
  3. Severe cases including immunocompromised (HIV, transplant recipients, malignancy): discharge will be based on clinical recovery and should be tested negative once by RT-PCR after resolution of symptoms.

Other options:

Option A: Invasive aspergillosis leads to the formation of black or greyish membrane in the nasal mucosa. The maxillary sinus may contain a fungus ball containing semisolid cheesy-white or blackish material.

Option C: Foreign body nose presents with foul-smelling unilateral discharge.

Option D: Rhinosporidiosis is a granulomatous condition caused by Rhinosporidium seeberi and presents with nasal discharge, epistaxis, and nasal obstruction by a polypoidal mass.

questions.text: Which of the following surgery is done commonly in Tubotympanic type of CSOM?
questions.solution:
Tympanoplasty is done commonly in Tubotympanic type of CSOM.

It is the eradication of disease from the middle ear and reconstruction of hearing (ossiculoplasty) with or without grafting of the tympanic membrane.

Myringoplasty is the term given for closure of perforation of tympanic membrane done to check repeated infections from external ear.

questions.text: A 35-year-old pregnant female patient complains of hearing loss, which is aggravated during pregnancy. Tympanometry shows As a type of graph. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the tympanometry showing As type of graph are suggestive of otosclerosis. As type of curve indicates that pressure is normal but compliance is reduced which is seen in otosclerosis.

Otosclerosis:

It has an autosomal dominant inheritance and usually presents with bilateral progressive conductive hearing loss. It is known to be initiated or worsened by stress & hormonal variations like during pregnancy, trauma, surgery, menopause. Otosclerosis is a primary disease of the bony labyrinth where foci of irregularly placed spongy bone replace part of the normally dense enchondral layer of the bony otic capsule. Most often, otosclerotic focus involves the stapes region leading to stapes fixation and conductive deafness.

The most common type of otosclerosis is stapedial otosclerosis. Here lesion starts just in front of the oval window in an area called fissula ante fenestram. The patients will have painless bilateral conductive hearing loss, tinnitus, and vertigo. An otosclerotic patient hears better in noisy than in quiet surroundings. This is because a normal person will raise his voice in noisy surroundings. This is called paracusis willisii.

On examination, the tympanic membrane may appear normal. In some patients, a reddish hue over the promontory may be visible through the tympanic membrane. This is called the Schwartze sign.

Tuning fork tests and audiometry will reveal the presence of conductive hearing loss. Bone conduction curve may show a dip, which is maximum at 2000Hz. This is called Carhart’s notch. Tympanogram will show the presence of As type of curve. 

Management:

The treatment of choice is stapedectomy/stapedotomy with the placement of the prosthesis. The fixed otosclerotic stapes is removed and a prosthesis (like Teflon piston, stainless steel piston, platinum–Teflon or titanium–Teflon piston) is inserted between the incus and oval window.

Related Pearl: Types of curves in tympanogram

Type A:

Indicates normal pressure and normal compliance in a normal ear.

 

Type B: 

Flat or dome-shaped graph i.e. reduced compliance. Seen in serous otitis media.

The flat curve is a type of B type curve seen with a perforated tympanic membrane. The volume measurement that is simultaneously performed with tympanometry helps to differentiate between a flat tympanogram suggesting an intact eardrum with middle ear effusion versus a perforated eardrum or ear with a patent ventilating tube.

 

Type C:

Indicates normal compliance but negative pressure due to eustachian tube obstruction.

Seen with a retracted tympanic membrane and in early stages before fluid collects in the middle ear.

 

Type As:

Indicates reduced compliance (‘s’ means stiffness leading to reduced compliance) and normal pressure.

Seen in Otosclerosis or other ossicular fixation and Tympanosclerosis.

 

Type Ad: 

Indicates increased compliance (‘d’ means discontinuity leading to increased mobility) and normal pressure.

Seen in ossicular discontinuity and with thin and lax TM.
