questions.text: A 60-year-old trumpet player presents with hoarseness, cough, and neck swelling as shown in the image below. The swelling is reducible in the neck which increases in size on coughing and performing Valsalva maneuver. The given presentation is due to an enlarged diverticulum in ________
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario suggests laryngocele and it occurs due to abnormal distention of saccule present in the ventricle of the larynx(sinus of the larynx).

Ventricle (sinus of larynx):

  • It is a deep elliptical space between vestibular and vocal folds.
  • The saccule is a diverticulum of mucous membrane which starts from the anterior part of the ventricular cavity and extends upwards between vestibular folds and lamina of thyroid
  • When abnormally enlarged and distended, it may form a Laryngocele - an air containing sac which may present in the neck.

Laryngocele is an air-filled cystic swelling due to dilatation of the saccule. It is seen in trumpet players, glass-blowers or weight lifters due to raised transglottic air pressure. It can be internal, external or combined. External laryngocele presents as a reducible swelling in the neck which increases in size on coughing or performing Valsalva manoeuvre.

Management: Internal laryngocele is manged by marsupialization and surgical excision through an external neck incision for external laryngocele.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs used in the medical management of Meniere's disease, acts by causing dilatation of the labyrinthine blood vessels?
questions.solution:
Betahistine (vertin), used in the medical management of Meniere's disease acts by causing dilatation of the labyrinthine blood vessels, thereby improving the microvascular circulation in the stria vascularis of the cochlea. It is also found to inhibit the vestibular nuclei activity.

Other drugs used in the medical management of Meniere's disease are

  • Prochlorperazine (stemetil), is a vestibular sedative.
  • Diuretics such as furosemide and hydrochlorothiazide are used to control recurrent attacks.
  • Propantheline bromide (probanthine), an anticholinergic agent is also found to be effective.

questions.text:
An MRI scan of a 40-year-old male who presented with hearing difficulty, frequent episodes of tinnitus, and imbalance is given below. Which of the following statements are correct considering the likely diagnosis?
  1. The patient will have poor speech discrimination that is disproportionate to pure-tone hearing loss
  2. Roll-over phenomenon is seen
  3. External beam radiotherapy is the treatment of choice
  4. Most commonly arises from the cochlear division of the VIIIth nerve
  5. Recruitment phenomenon is present
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette and MRI scan are suggestive of acoustic neuroma. Here, the patient will have poor speech discrimination that is disproportionate to pure-tone hearing loss, and roll-over phenomenon is seen making statements 1 and 2 correct.

Acoustic neuroma is a schwannoma more commonly arising from the superior and the inferior division of the vestibular nerve and less commonly from the cochlear nerve, in the medial internal auditory canal at the site of transition of central to peripheral myelin i.e. Obersteiner-Redlich zone.

It is the most common cerebellopontine angle tumor. It is a slow-growing tumor and mostly affects middle-aged and elderly individuals. Bilateral acoustic schwannomas are strongly suggestive of neurofibromatosis type 2. Clinically, patients with acoustic neuroma present with the following features-

  • Cochleovestibular symptoms- They are the earliest symptoms.
    • Progressive unilateral sensorineural hearing loss with higher frequencies affected first
    • Tinnitus
    • Unsteadiness and imbalance
    • Poor speech discrimination on speech audiometry disproportionate to the hearing loss
    • Absent recruitment phenomenon
    • Roll-over phenomenon- Reduction in discrimination score when loudness is increased beyond a particular limit. 
  • Other cranial nerve involvement
    • Reduced corneal sensitivity, numbness, or paraesthesia of face due to involvement of the trigeminal nerve
    • Hitzelberger’s sign- Hypoaesthesia of the posterior meatal wall when the tumor affects the sensory fibers of the facial nerve
    • Dysphagia and hoarseness due to palatal, pharyngeal and laryngeal paralysis due to glossopharyngeal and vagus nerve involvement. 

MRI with Gadolinium contrast is the gold standard for the diagnosis of acoustic neuroma. The mass will be seen extending into the intracanalicular portion of the internal acoustic meatus. Extracanalicular extension into the cerebellopontine angle along the path of least resistance can lead to an "ice-cream-cone" appearance.

Surgical removal of the tumor is the treatment of choice. The approach depends on the site and size of the tumor and includes the middle cranial fossa approach, translabyrinthine approach, retrosigmoid/suboccipital approach, or combined approach. External beam radiation is not recommended as it causes significant damage to the surrounding brain and neural structures. Stereotactic radiosurgery is a reasonable alternative for people who refuse/cannot tolerate surgery. Here, beams are modified and focused only to concentrate on the tumor and have little effect on surrounding tissue. It can be done by using X-knife using LINAC, Gamma-knife using Cobalt 60, and Cyber-knife.

questions.text: What clinical test is depicted in the image?
questions.solution:
The clinical test depicted in the image is Cottle’s test where the cheek is drawn laterally while the patient breathes quietly. 

This test is used to assess the patency of the nasal valve in patients with a deviated nasal septum. If the nasal airway improves on the test side, the test is positive and indicates an abnormality of the vestibular component of the nasal valve on that side.

Option A: Epley’s maneuver is used in the treatment of BPPV.

 

Option B: Heimlich manoeuvre is used in the treatment of accidental inhalation of foreign body. Procedure: Stand behind the person and place your arms around his lower chest and give four abdominal thrusts. The residual air in the lungs can dislodge the foreign body providing some airway.

 

Option D: Trotter’s method is used in the treatment of epistaxis. In Trotter’s method, the patient is made to sit, leaning a little forward over a basin to spit any blood. He should pinch the nose firmly for 5 to 10 mins and breathe quietly from the mouth.

questions.text: A 14-year-old male presented with recurrent epistaxis. There is no history of trauma associated with it. He also complained of nasal obstruction and rhinorrhea. On examination, there is a firm purplish mass on the posterior nasopharynx. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis is Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma.

Adolescent male presenting with recurrent epistaxis, nasal obstruction, and purplish mass on the posterior nasopharynx points towards angiofibroma. The consistency of the tumor is firm but the digital palpation should never be done until at the time of operation, because of the risk of profuse bleeding.

 

Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma: Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma (JNA) is a highly vascular and locally aggressive tumour seen almost exclusively in adolescent males, associated with significant morbidity and occasional mortality. JNA accounts for only 0.05% of all head and neck tumours.

Patients usually present with a triad of

  • Progressive nasal obstruction,
  • Recurrent epistaxis and
  • Mass in the nasal cavity and nasopharynx.

It has the potency to cause proptosis, affecting both the orbit and with intracranial extension, eventually leading to cranial nerve palsies and loss of vision.

Angiofibroma can be diagnosed using CT, MRI, and magnetic resonance angiography. Anterior bowing of the maxillary wall due to the presence of a mass in the pterygomaxillary space on CT known as the Holman-Miller sign is a characteristic finding of JNA.

Recurrence has been reported up to 35%.

Management: Surgical excision is the treatment of choice. Recurrent angiofibroma is treated with revision surgery, Radiotherapy is considered where the recurrence tumour is inaccessible.

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy comes with complaints of right ear pain, difficulty in opening the mouth, painful swallowing, and fever. The oral cavity examination reveals the following. The external facial examination is unremarkable. Which of the following is likely?
questions.solution:
The image shows quinsy also known as a peritonsillar abscess. 

Quinsy:

Quinsy is the collection of pus between the fibrous capsule of the tonsil and the superior constrictor muscles of the pharynx.

Clinical features: 

  • Sore throat/ Dysphagia 
  • Drooling of saliva 
  • Trismus 
  • Ipsilateral otalgia 
  • Fever 

Management of quinsy

  • Hospitalization
  • Intravenous fluids to combat dehydration
  • Antibiotics - Suitable antibiotics in large  i.v. doses to cover aerobes and anaerobes;
  • Analgesics like paracetamol are given for pain relief
  • Oral hygiene should be maintained by hydrogen peroxide or saline mouthwashes.
  • Drainage by needle aspiration, incision, and drainage or tonsillectomy.
  • Incision and drainage of the abscess: A peritonsillar abscess is opened at the point of the maximum bulge above the upper pole of the tonsil or just lateral to the point of junction of the anterior pillar with a line drawn through the base of the uvula.

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis from the image given below?
questions.solution:
The likely diagnosis, based on the above image, is pterygium. 

Pterygium is a subconjunctival fibrovascular tissue encroaching the cornea. It is a degenerative condition of the sub-conjunctival tissue and is never inflammatory. It occurs due to exposure to UV-B radiation and the most common site is the nasal.

It is made up of three parts-a "cap" (an avascular halo-like zone at the advancing edge), a head, and a body.

Clinical features:

  • Astigmatism with the rule - most common finding
  • Stocker's line - deposition of iron on the advancing edge
  • Fuchs islets - small, discrete, whitish flecks consisting of clusters of pterygial epithelial cells, often present at the advancing edge.

The differential diagnosis is pseudo pterygium. 

Pterygium Pseudo-pterygium
Degenerative process Inflammatory process
Occurs in elderly  Can occur at any age
Situated at the palpebral aperture Can occur at any site
Either progressive, regressive, or stationary Always stationary
A probe cannot be passed underneath A probe can be passed under the neck

The treatment for pterygium is usually excision. To prevent a recurrence, mitomycin C or 5 fluorouracil is used. Other methods:

  • Auto-grafting- Conjunctival limbal autograft (CLAG) from the superior limbal conjunctiva is the best method.
  • Bare sclera technique- high recurrence rate of 30 to 80%.
  • PERFECT surgery- zero rates of recurrence. (PERFECT stands for Pterygium Extended Removal Followed by Extended Conjunctival Transplant)

questions.text: A 53-year-old woman presented with difficulty reading and a visual blur in both the eyes. On evaluation, her vision on Snellen’s chart was 6/6 on both eyes. Fundus examination was normal. Visual field charting shows the following defect. Where is the site of the lesion?
questions.solution:
The visual field defect shown in the image is bitemporal hemianopia. The site of the lesion is the optic chiasma due to the decussation of nasal fibres.

Other notable visual field defects:

  • Pie in the sky defects
    • Superior quadrantic hemianopia
    • Involvement of Meyer’s loop - inferior fibres of optic radiations
    • Contralateral temporal lobe
  • Pie in the floor defects
    • Inferior quadrantic hemianopia
    • Involvement of Baum’s loop - superior fibres of optic radiations
    • Contralateral parietal lobe
  • Homonymous hemianopia
    • Involvement of retrochiasmal regions such as optic tract, geniculate body, optic radiations.
    • Sparing of the macula and more congruous field defect (both sides have the same extent of field loss) when the occipital cortex is involved.

Related Pearl: Lesions in the optic pathway

Transection of the pathways at the locations indicated by the letters causes the visual field defects shown in the diagram above.

  • The fibers from the nasal half of each retina decussate in the optic chiasm, so that the fibers in the optic tracts are those from the temporal half of one retina and the nasal half of the other.
  • A lesion that interrupts the optic nerve causes blindness in that eye.
  • Lesions affecting the optic chiasma destroy fibers from both nasal hemiretinas and produce a heteronymous (opposite sides of the visual fields) hemianopia.
  • A lesion in one optic tract causes blindness in half of the visual field and is called homonymous (same side of both visual fields) hemianopia (half-blindness).
  • Occipital lesions may spare the fibers from the macula because of the separation in the brain of these fibers from the other subserving vision.

questions.text: Stellate Keratitic precipitates are commonly seen in_____________
questions.solution:
Stellate Keratic precipitates are commonly seen in Fuch’s heterochromic iridocyclitis.

Fuch’s heterochromic iridocyclitis: It is insidious onset, unilateral, non granulomatous anterior uveitis.

Stellate/star shaped keratic precipiates are seen. Posterior synechae are absent.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male patient who went swimming in a lake, presented with complaints of foreign body sensation, pain, and photophobia in the left eye. There is a history of contact lens use. An image of the eye is given below. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above case scenario is suggestive of acanthamoeba keratitis. The image depicts a ring lesion (abscess) of Acanthamoeba keratitis.

Acanthamoeba keratitis

  • Rare protozoal infection of the cornea
  • Occurs in soft contact lens users who wash their lens with tap water
  • Pain is disproportionately more due to perineural invasion.
  • Presents as
    • Ring lesion (most common)
    • Pseudo dendrites
    • Reticular pattern
  • Investigation
    • Staining – Calcofluor White, Acridine Orange, Lactophenol Blue
    • Culture – Non-nutrient agar with E.coli
  • Treatment
    • Based on the eradication of cysts
    • First line - Chlorhexidine and Poly-hexamethylene biguanide (PHMB)
    • Second line - Pentamidine

Related Pearl: Clinical differential diagnosis of corneal ulcer

  Bacterial Fungal Viral Parasitic
Risk factors

Contact lens wear

Trauma

Chronic steroid use

Anesthetic cornea

Dry eyes

Exposure keratopathy

 Trauma with vegetable matter

Low immunity

Recurrent attacks

Contact lens wear

Exposure to contaminated water (acanthamoeba)

 
Clinical features

Hypopyon is fluid and mobile

Pseudomonas aeruginosa is likely to have a rapid course, with deep corneal necrosis.

Less pain and watering compared to the extent of vision loss and signs. 

Tend to be indolent but progressive

Hypopyon is thick, immobile.

Relatively more pain and watering compared to the extent of vision loss and signs. 

Recurrences are characteristic.

Disproportionately severe pain is a characteristic feature.

Indolent course and in initial stages, often mistaken to be viral/ fungal infection, leading to a delay in diagnosis

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding accommodative esotropia?

choices.text: It is the most common type of squint.
Miotics are used as the treatment strategy in the high AC/A ratio
It is associated with high myopia.
Refractive type can be fully corrected by use of spectacles.

questions.solution:
Accommodative esotropia is associated with a high degree of hypermetropia (+4 to +7 D).

Accommodative esotropia is the most common type of squint. Typically presents around 2 to 3 years of age.

Types:

  1. Refractive
    • Associated with high hypermetropia
    • Fully correctable by spectacles
  2. Non-refractive type
    • Abnormal accommodative convergence/accommodation (AC/A) ratio
    • Fully corrected by bifocal glasses
    • Miotics useful in cases where glasses are unsuitable
      • Echothiophate causes iris cyst
      • Prevention of iris cysts- Phenylephrine drops
  3. Mixed type

The accommodative convergence/accommodation (AC/A) ratio is defined as the amount of convergence measured in prism diopters per unit (diopter) change in accommodation.

The image below shows accommodative esotropia with and without correction.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy presented with a whitish pupillary reflex for which enucleation was done. The histopathological examination of the specimen revealed Flexner Wintersteiner rosettes. What could be the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis in a 7-year-old child with a whitish pupillary reflex with the presence of Flexner Winterstein rosettes on histopathological examination is retinoblastoma. Flexner Winterstein rosettes refer to an arrangement of columnar cells around a central lumen, which is highly characteristic of retinoblastoma.

Retinoblastoma is a malignant proliferation of the immature retinal neural cells and is the most common intraocular malignancy in children. It is associated with mutations in the RB1 gene at chromosome 13q14. It is a tumor of a group called small round blue cell tumors because the immature retinal neural cells are seen as small round cells with large nuclei.

White pupillary reflex or leukocoria is the most common presenting feature, followed by a squint which is usually convergent. Rarely, the child may present with nystagmus and defective vision.

Image showing leukocoria of left eye

Histopathology of the tumor shows small round cells with large nuclei. Microscopic features of a well-differentiated tumor include Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes (highly specific of retinoblastoma), Homer-Wright rosettes, pseudorosettes, and fleurettes formation. Areas of necrosis and calcification can also be seen.

The histopathological image of retinoblastoma is shown below.

Treatment typically involves chemotherapy plus focal therapy. The commonly used three-drug regimen is the CVE regimen consisting of Vincristine, Carboplatin, Etoposide. Focal therapy includes cryotherapy, laser photocoagulation, thermotherapy, plaque radiotherapy, and external beam radiotherapy.
Enucleation is done when
  • the tumor involves more than half of the retina
  • the optic nerve is involved
  • glaucoma is present and the anterior chamber is involved

In the stage of extraocular extension, the globe bursts through the sclera, usually near the limbus or near the optic disc. This is followed by rapid fungation and involvement of extraocular tissues results in marked proptosis.
Distant metastasis occurs through the lymphatic spread and the direct extension by continuity to the optic nerve and brain.

questions.text: Identify the instrument.
questions.solution:
The given image is that of an enucleation spoon. This is identified by the central cleavage that engages the optic nerve in enucleation.

Other options

Option A- Evisceration spatula consists of a small but stout rectangular blade with a slightly convex surface and blunt edges attached to a handle. It is used to separate out the uveal tissue from the sclera during evisceration operation.

Option C- Chalazion clamp consists of two limbs like forceps, which can be clamped with the help of a screw. The tip of one limb is flattened in the
form of a round disc while the tip of the other arm has a small circular ring. It is used to fix the chalazion and achieve hemostasis during the incision and curettage operation.

Option D- Bone punch consists of a stout spring handle and two blades attached at a right angle. It is used to enlarge the bony opening during
dacryocystorhinostomy (DCR) operation by punching the bone from the margins of the opening.

questions.text: Identify the instrument_____
questions.solution:
The device shown in the image is a Slit Lamp.

  • It can be used to visualise the anterior and posterior chambers of the eye. It cannot be used to visualise the retina directly, because of the refractive power of ocular media.
  • Most slit-lamp microscopes offer magnifications between ×5 and ×50, with ×10, ×16, and ×25 being the most popular. Image resolution is ultimately limited by diffraction.
  • Because the cornea has such high refractive power, the slit-lamp microscope can view only the first one-third of the eye. 

Slit lamps are not useful beyond the anterior part of the vitreous as the focal point is generally in this region. Using a contact lens with a flat anterior face or a high power convex or concave lens however can diverge the beam by eliminating the refractive influence of the corneal curvature and thereby overcome this shortcoming. Special lenses, in conjunction with the slit-lamp microscope, can be used to view the posterior vitreous and the posterior pole of the retina.

The lenses used are as follows:

  • Contact type: Goldmann three-mirror contact lens, modified Koeppe lens.
  • Non-contact type: Convex lens +60D, +78D, +90D (best lens). Hruby lens is a planoconcave lens with dioptric power of -55D.

Other options - 

Image: Humphrey's Visual field analyzer

Image: Keratometer

Image: Ophthalmoscope

questions.text: Identify the type of study from the following design.
questions.solution:
The study design given is a prospective cohort study. The study proceeds from cause to effect.

Framingham Heart Study is one of the most famous long-term cardiovascular cohort studies.

Related Pearl: Cohort Study

  • A cohort study progresses from cause to effect, as exposure has occured but not disease.
  • It is also known as forward-looking study, incidence study, prospective study, and longitudinal study.
  • Design of a Cohort Study
    • Types
      • Prospective cohort studies (concurrent cohort studies)
      • Retrospective cohort studies (historical cohort study)
      • Combination cohort studies
    • Steps
      • Selection of study subjects
      • Obtaining data on exposure
      • Selection of comparison groups
      • Follow-up
      • Analysis in terms of incidence rates and estimation of risk
    • Advantages and disadvantages

Advantages

Disadvantages

Incidence can be calculated.

Several possible outcomes related to exposure can be studied at same time.

Provides direct estimate of relative risk

Calculation of dose-response ratio

Minimization of certain biases

Cannot be used for uncommon diseases

Uses a large population

Takes a long time to complete

Many common administrative problems

Attrition is high.

Selection of subjects is difficult.

Dynamism of diagnostics is difficult to incorporate.

Tend to be expensive.

Tends to alter behaviour of subjects: Hawthorne effect.

Ethical problems

Related Pearl: Case Control Study

  • In a case control study, progression is from effect to cause as outcome or disease has already occurred.
  • It is also called retrospective study.
  • Design of Case Control Study

 

    • Steps of Case Control Study
      • Selection of cases and controls
      • Matching
      • Measurement of exposure
      • Analysis in the form of exposure rates, risk ratio, and odds ratio
    • Advantages and Disadvantages

Advantages

Disadvantages

Easy to carry out

Rapid and inexpensive

Requires few subjects

Used to investigate rare diseases

No risk to subjects

Different etiological factors can be studied.

Risk factors can be identified.

No attrition problems

Minimal ethical problems

Relies on memory or past records which can give rise to bias

Selection of appropriate control groups may be difficult.

Incidence cannot be measured.

Does not distinguish between causes and associated factors

Not suited for evaluation of therapy or prophylaxis

Representativeness of the cases and controls is often inadequate.

In this scenario:

Specificity is given as TN/(FP + TN) x 100. Thus, specitivity is 93%.

Related Pearl: Validity of a Screening Test

  • Validity/ Accuracy of a screening test depends upon the sensitivity, specificity, and predictive accuracy of the test.
  • It represents the closeness to a true value/ actual value.
  • These are the inherent properties of a screening test.
  • PPV and NPV are dependent on the Prevalence of disease.
  • Sensitivity & Speciifity are independent of prevalence of disease.

questions.text: The following diagram charts the HDL values in a given population. What is the statistical diagram used here?
questions.solution:
The given image shows Frequency polygons.

Frequency polygons:

  • Frequency polygons are used for ratio and interval scale data.
  • In a frequency polygon, the mid-points of each class interval are joined together by straight lines.

Related Pearl: Graphical Representation of Data

1. Histogram

  • A histogram, by definition, is a graphical representation of frequency distribution that contains rectangles and shows the underlying frequency of a set of continuous, quantitative data.
  • The X or horizontal axis is called the abscissa which usually has the group scores or class intervals of the variables/data and the Y or vertical axis is called the ordinate which usually shows the frequencies at which these variables appear.
  • The following is a histogram of cholesterol levels from the Framingham Heart Study.

2. Bar Chart

  • It is also called a bar graph.
  • It is used mainly for nominal or ordinal scale data as they are not quantitative and usually qualitative.
  • The difference between a bar graph and a histogram is that the rectangles are separated by spaces representing data that forms discrete categories instead of continuous groups.
  • Bar graphs can be simple, multiple or component bar graphs.

3. Pie Charts

  • Pie charts are also used for nominal or ordinal data.
  • The categorical data are represented as segments of a circle.

4. Frequency polygons

  • Frequency polygons are used for mainly ratio and interval scale data.
  • In a frequency polygon, the mid-points of each class interval are joined together by straight lines.

5. Ogive

  • A frequency polygon which is drawn to represent cumulative frequency distributions form a typical S-shaped curve which is called an ogive. It referred to as a cumulative frequency diagram.

6. Line chart

  • It is also called a line diagram or line graph.
  • Its best use is to show the trend of events or change over passage of time.

questions.text: A study was done to assess nutritional status among young children in rural and urban areas. 40 children in rural and 30 children in urban areas were malnourished. Which of the following tests of significance is the most appropriate in this case?
questions.solution:
The most appropriate test of significance, in this case, is the chi-square test. It is used to compare qualitative data between 2 groups with independent measures.

In this question,

  • Nutritional status (nourished or malnourished) is a qualitative measure.
  • Residence (Urban or rural) is again a qualitative measure.
  • Further, only these TWO variables are being compared. Therefore, the chi-square test is the most appropriate test of significance.

The Chi-Square test (χ2) is a non-parametric(non-numeric) test and it is used to test hypotheses in relation to nominal scale data or categorical data.

  • It is a test of proportions and associations.
  • A Chi-square distribution is usually positively skewed but it approaches a normal distribution as its degrees of freedom increases.
  • If the frequency of any of the cells of the categorical table is <5, then Fisher’s exact test is used.

Other options:

Option B: Paired t-test compares paired data or pre-intervention and post-intervention data of the same group. This doesn't apply here as the groups are not paired.

Option C: Standard error of the mean is calculated for quantitative data, with measure of central tendency as mean.

Option D: The analysis of variance test (ANOVA) is used to test the difference between two or usually more than two groups (means) and here the inferences are made by analyzing the variances.

Related Pearl: Tests of Significance

How to choose which test to use?

  • See the variable. Are the variables quantitative or qualitative?
    • If the variables are qualitative (nominal), then Chi square test is used.
    • If the variables are quantitative, then see whether 2 groups are being tested, or more than 2 groups.
      • If 2 groups are being tested, then T tests are used. In that, if the same group is tested before and after, paired T test is used. Otherwise, unpaired T test is used.
      • If more than 2 groups are being tested, then use ANOVA.

The tests:

1. T Tests

  • Unpaired t tests
    • Also known as the student’s t test, independent t test, two-samples t test.
    • It's the most commonly used t test and it tests the difference between two groups (the means of 2 groups) independent of each other and indicates how significant the differences are.
  • Paired t tests
    • "Pairs before marriage are not the same after!"
    • So remember paired test is mainly used in comparison of a before and after scenario 
    • Also known as correlated t test, dependent samples t test.
    • It is mainly used on dependent samples For example, the cholesterol level of a person before and after using a specific drug.
    • It can also be used when you put the same condition under test using different items or things. For example, same crash safety tests for different cars.
  • T scores 
    • The t score is referred to as the ratio of the difference between two groups and the difference within the groups.
    • The smaller the t score, the more similarity there is between two groups and vice versa.

 

2. Analysis of Variance (ANOVA)

  • The analysis of variance test (ANOVA) is used to test the difference between two or usually more than two groups (means) and here the inferences are made by analyzing the variances.

 

3. Chi-Square Test

  • The Chi-Square test (χ2) is a non-parametric(non-numeric) test and it is used to test hypotheses in relation to nominal scale data or categorical data.
  • It is a test of proportions and associations.
  • A Chi-square distribution is usually positively skewed but it approaches a normal distribution as its degrees of freedom increases.
  • If the frequency of any of the cells of the categorical table is <5, then Fisher’s exact test is used.

questions.text:
A woman brought her 14-month-old child to the PHC for routine immunization. The child was born in February 2020 at home and has not received any vaccine till now due to lockdown. The mother is apprehensive of her child's health and wants to immunize him. Which of the following vaccines can be given to the child now?
  1. OPV
  2. Measles
  3. BCG
  4. Vitamin A
  5. Pentavalent
questions.solution:
In this case of an unimmunized child, OPV, measles, and vitamin A vaccines can be given but BCG and Pentavalent are not given as the child is 14 months old now.

Catch-up vaccination involves the administration of vaccines in children who have not been immunized at all (left-outs) or for children who took vaccines but couldn't complete the course(dropouts). Efforts should be made to ensure that all vaccines are given at the recommended ages, or closer to it. However, certain vaccines have an age limit till which they can be given. This is because the child develops immunity against a few diseases or is no longer vulnerable. 

BCG can only be given up to 1 year of age, according to the National Immunisation Schedule. 

Please note that BCG can be given up to 5 years of age, as part of the catch-up immunization schedule which is by the Indian Academy of Paediatrics but that is not followed in government setups like PHC.

OPV can be given till 5 years of age.

Measles can be given till 5 years of age.

DPT can be given until 7 years of age (with booster doses).

Only the above-mentioned vaccines have upper age limits. 

For pentavalent, IPV, PCV, and Rotavirus vaccines, if at least one dose is given before one year of age, then remaining doses can be administered and the schedule must be completed irrespective of the age of the child. If the first dose is not administered before one year of age, then these vaccines cannot be administered to the child under UIP.

questions.text: A 30-year-old pregnant woman in her third trimester was found to be positive for plasmodium falciparum malaria. What treatment would she be started on?
questions.solution:

Treatment of vivax malaria during pregnancy:

Primaquine is contraindicated in pregnancy.

questions.text: The Pathanamthitta district of Kerala was affected by floods and the government distributed doxycycline tablets for prophylaxis. Which other chemical will be distributed along with it?
questions.solution:
Leptospirosis, followed by acute diarrhoeal diseases and dengue are most commonly prevalent following floods in Kerala. Malathion will be the choice of insecticide used in this scenario.

Leptospirosis is a bacterial zoonotic disease transmitted via water contaminated with rodent urine. Infected rodents excrete large amounts of leptospira in their urine and floods facilitate the spread of the organism.

Prevention of leptospirosis:

  • Chemoprophylaxis with Doxycycline 200 mg once a week for 6 weeks is recommended for high-risk populations in endemic areas. In case of fever, Doxycycline 100 mg twice a day for seven days is the recommended dose.
  • Rubber shoes and gloves should be used.
  • Anti-rodent measures must be taken.
  • Mapping of water bodies must be done to establish a proper drainage system.

Other diseases usually transmitted after floods are typhoid fever, malaria, cholera, hepatitis A & E.

General measures to control disease spread during floods are:

  • Chlorine tablets are distributed to disinfect the household water supply. One tablet can chlorinate 20 liters of water. Drinking water disinfectants like bleaching powder are also used.
  • Malathion is an organophosphorus synthetic insecticide used for vector control (adult mosquitoes). It is a contact poison that is sprayed using ultra-light volume fogging machines.
  • Indoor residual sprays with insecticides and larvicides like abate for drinking water are recommended.
  • Tetanus booster dose for previously vaccinated people with open injuries may be indicated.
  • General hygiene and sanitary measures must be followed.

Other health risks posed by floods are hypothermia, respiratory tract infections, snake bites and injuries/drowning.

Related Pearl: Insecticides

Contact poisons

  • Natural: Pyrethrum, rotenone, derris, nicotine, mineral oils
  • Synthetic:
    • Organo-chlorine compounds: DDT, methoxychlor, HCH, lindane, chlordane, heptachlor, dieldrin, aldrin, toxaphene, kepone, mirex.
    • Repellants: Benzyl benzoate, indalone, meta-diethyltoluamide, dimethyl phthalate, ethyl hexanediol.
    • Organo-phosphorus compounds: Chlorthion (aryl), diazinon (aryl), demethoate, malathion (alkyl), fenthion, parathion (aryl), trichlorfon (alkyl), runnel, abale, naled, chlorpyrifos, fenitrothion, dicapthon.
    • Carbamates: Carbaryl, dimetilan, propoxur, pyrolan.
    • Synthetic pyrethroids: Prothrin, resmethrin, bioresmethrin, permethrin, proparthin, tetramethrin
  • Stomach poisons: Paris green, sodium fluoride.
  • Fumigants: Hydrogen cyanide, methyl bromide, sulphur dioxide, carbon disulphide.
Specific Insecticides Comments
DDT (Dichloro-diphenyl-thrichloroethane) Insecticidal properties were discovered by Swiss scientist, Paul Muller. Most widely used insecticide. Attacks nerves of insects but doesn’t cause immediate death. White amorphous powder. Contains 70 – 80% of para-para isomers, which is the most active fraction of DDT. Has residual action up to 18 months. Used as a residual spray.Least toxic organo-chlorine compound.
HCH (hexachlorocyclo-hexane) Synthesized by Michael Faraday. Normal HCH contains 13 – 16% of gamma isomer. Gamma-HCH or lindane has 99% gamma isomer.Short residual action – 3 months.
Malathion Least toxicity of all organophosphorus compounds. Used as an ultra-low volume spray.
Fenthion Also called baytex. Used as a residual spray.
Pyrethrum Vegetable origin – Chrysanthemum cinerariafolium. Nerve poison and is excellent as a space spray.No residual action.Synergistic action with DDT as space spray.

questions.text: Which of the following was launched to ensure complete immunization of children?
questions.solution:
Mission Indradhanush was launched by the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare to fully immunize children (>90%) who are either partially immunized or completely unimmunized by 2020. It has been now modified to the Intensified Mission Indradhanush, which targets the same goal by December 2018. 

It now includes 12 vaccine-preventable diseases (updated from the 7 VPDs that Mission Indradhanush focussed on). 4 rounds of immunization are proposed to be held for 7 days each month (from the 7th- 13th of each month). The diseases include:

  • TB
  • Polio
  • Hep B
  • Diphtheria
  • Pertussis
  • Tetanus
  • Measles

The ones included recently are:

  • Rotavirus diarrhoea
  • Rubella (as MR vaccine)
  • H. influenzae B diseases (as part of the pentavalent vaccine)
  • Pneumococcal meningitis
  • Japanese Encephalitis

questions.text: The Chest X-ray of a presumptive TB patient who presented with dry cough and weight loss is suggestive, but the sputum examination is negative. As per the National Tuberculosis Elimination Programme guidelines, what should be the next step in management?

choices.text: Give antibiotics and repeat chest X-ray

questions.solution:
A patient with a suggestive CXR but sputum smear-negative should undergo a CB-NAAT as the next step in management.


Nucleic Acid Amplification Test (NAAT) provides an accurate and rapid diagnosis of TB by detecting Mycobacterium tuberculosis and Rifampicin (Rif) resistance-conferring mutations, in sputum specimens as well as a specimen from extra-pulmonary sites. Under the program, its use is recommended for diagnosis of DR-TB in presumptive DR-TB patients and TB preferentially in the key population such as children, PLHIV, Extra-pulmonary TB, and in smear-negative TB as per the diagnostic algorithm. 

 

Related Pearl: Diagnostic algorithm for Pulmonary TB – National Tuberculosis Elimination Programme (NTEP) 2020 Guidelines

A presumptive pulmonary TB patient should undergo both Sputum examination and Chest X-ray.

If sputum and CXR is negative, CB NAAT should be done when the clinical suspicion is high:

As is inferred from the above table, irrespective of chest X ray findings, CB-NAAT is done in all cases where sputum examination is negative for diagnosis.

CB-NAAT is also performed in all microbiologically confirmed and notified cases of TB for drug susceptibility testing.

The following protocol is used for CB-NAAT testing:

Related Pearl: ATT Regimen for TB Patients

As per the latest recommendations from National Tuberculosis Elimination Programme (NTEP), treatment of TB is now based primarily on drug susceptibility testing. This is irrespective of new cases, previously treated cases or recurrent TB cases. 
All cases of TB are treated with Drug Sensitive TB Regimen, as long as the patient is sensitive to isoniazid and rifampicin. (No classification into category I or II)

Type of TB Case Intensive Phase Continuation Phase
New and previously treated cases (H and R sensitive) 2 H R Z E 4 H R E

Classification based on drug resistance

  • Mono-resistant (MR): A TB patient, who is resistant to one 1st line anti-TB drug only.
  • Poly-Drug Resistant (PDR): A TB patient, who is resistant to more than one 1st line anti-TB drug, other than Rifampicin. 
  • Rifampicin Resistant (RR): A TB patient, who is resistant to rifampicin with or without resistance to other drugs. Patients, who have rifampicin resistance, should be managed as if they are an MDR TB case.
  • Multi Drug Resistant (MDR): A TB patient, who is resistant to both isoniazid and rifampicin.
  • Extensively Drug Resistant (XDR): A MDR TB patient who is additionally resistant to a fluoroquinolone (ofloxacin, levofloxacin, or moxifloxacin) and a second-line injectable anti TB drug (kanamycin, amikacin, or capreomycin).

Standard DR TB regimen

Regimen class Drugs Comments
H mono-resistant/ poly-drug resistant TB regimen Lfx R E Z for 6 months
  • 6 months long
  • Oral drugs only
Shorter MDR TB regimen

Intensive Phase:

Mfx Km/Am Eto Cfz Z H E for 4-6 months

Continuation phase:

Mfx Cfz Z E for 5 months
  • 9-11 months long
  • Injectables used in intensive phase.
Longer MDR TB regimen Bdq(6 months) Lfx Lzd Cfz Cs for 18-20 months
  • 18-20 months long
  • Oral drugs only
  • This regimen is used for XDR TB patients for 20 months.

Criteria for patients to receive standard Drug ResistantTB regimen

Standard Drug Resistant TB regimen Inclusion criteria Exclusion criteria
H mono-resistant/poly-drug resistant TB regimen Isoniazid resistant TB with rifampicin sensitive No specific criteria
Shorter MDR TB regimen Patient with rifampicin resistant pulmonary or extra pulmonary TB Non drug sensitivity test based criteria:
  • Pregnancy
  • Any extra pulmonary disease in PLHIV
  • Disseminated meningeal or central nervous system TB
  • Intolerance to any drug in the shorter MDR TB regimen
Drug sensitivity test based criteria:
  • If DST/DRT result for FQ or SLI is resistant (XDR TB)
  • Presence of InhA mutation
  • Resistant to Z 
Longer MDR TB regimen Patients in whom shorter MDR TB regimen cannot be considered due to any reason None

questions.text: In a leprosy case, the microbiologist documents the bacterial index according to Ridley's logarithmic scale and notes the value as 4+ for one of the smears. This value corresponds to:

choices.text: 10-100 bacilli, on average, in each oil-immersion field
100-1000 bacilli, on average, in each oil-immersion field
More than 1000 bacilli, on average, in each oil-immersion field
1-10 bacilli, on average, in 10 oil immersion fields

questions.solution:
In a leprosy split skin smear, according to Ridley's logarithmic scale, 4+ would mean 10-100 bacilli, on average, in each oil-immersion field.

The Bacteria Index(BI) is calculated by adding the index from each site examined and dividing the total by the number of sites examined.

 For Eg: If the bacilli found on each site are as:

  • Right ear: 5+
  • Left ear: 6+
  • Back: 4+
  • Chin: 5+

BI=(5+6+4+5)/4

BI=20/4

therefore, BI=5+

The given image is the emblem of the National Leprosy Eradication Programme(NLEP)

Characteristics of NLEP emblem :

  • The lotus in the NLEP Emblem symbolizes beauty and purity.
  • A partially affected thumb; a normal fore-finger and the shape of house symbolize that leprosy can be cured and a patient with leprosy can be a useful member of the society.
  • The rising sun symbolizes hope and optimism.
  • The Emblem captures the spirit of hope and positivity in the eradication of Leprosy.

The National Leprosy Eradication Programme is a centrally sponsored Health Scheme of the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare, Govt. of India.

Leprosy work is not merely medical relief; it is transforming frustration of life into joy of dedication, personal ambition into selfless service- Mahatma Gandhi.

 

Related Pearl: Ridley's logarithmic scale in determining Bacterial Index

Bacterial Index(BI) indicates the density of the leprosy bacilli in smears and includes both living and dead bacilli.

According to Ridley's logarithmic scale, the range is from 0 to 6+ and is based on the number of bacilli seen in an average microscopic field of the smear using an oil-immersion objective.

0

No bacilli in any of the 100 oil-immersion field

1+

1-10 bacilli, on average, in 100 oil-immersion field

2+

1-10 bacilli, on average, in 10 oil-immersion field

3+

1-10 bacilli, on average, in each oil-immersion field

4+

10-100 bacilli, on average, in each oil-immersion field

5+

100-1000 bacilli, on average, in each oil-immersion field 

6+

More than 1000 bacilli, on average, in each oil-immersion field 

BI is calculated by adding up the index from each site examined and dividing the total by the number of sites examined.

questions.text: A patient comes with a dirty and lacerated wound. He had received a full course of tetanus vaccination previously, his last dose being about 4 years back. Which of the following does he require?
questions.solution:
As the patient has completed his full course of tetanus vaccination with his last dose being less than 5 years, no additional action is needed.

A single dose tetanus toxoid to be given if the last dose was more than 5 years, and the wound was found to be dirty and lacerated.

Related Pearl: Post exposure prophylaxis for tetanus

Prophylaxis is given based on patient category:

  1. Full immunization or a booster dose within the past 5 years.
  2. Full immunization or a booster dose > 5 years ago but < 10 years.
  3. Full immunization or a booster dose > 10 years ago.
  4. Unknown or never taken immunization
Category Clean wound Unclean wound
A Only wound care Only wound care
B Wound care + TT single dose Wound care + TT single dose
C Wound care + TT single dose Wound care + TT single dose + Human tetanus immunoglobulin 
D Wound care + TT complete course Wound care + TT complete course + Human tetanus immunoglobulin

questions.text: To which of the following patients would you give 2 doses of rabies vaccine alone on day 0 and day 3?

choices.text: A 45 yr old unimmunized veterinarian who got a laceration by dog bite
A 23 yr old vaccinated woman who fed a stray dog which did not bite her
A 10 yr old vaccinated boy whose dog nibbled his toe but there was no bleeding
A 56 yr old unimmunized man whose dog licked his hand over intact skin

questions.solution:
This boy is a category II patient and treatment for him warrants wound management and rabies vaccine on days 0 and 3 (since the time of immunization is not mentioned).

Other options:

Options B and D: Are category I and do not require rabies prophylaxis.

Option A: Is category III and requires wound care, rabies immunoglobulin, and rabies vaccine.

Related Pearl: Rabies vaccines and immunoglobulins (WHO guidelines)

According to the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare, GOI:

Individuals with WHO category II or III exposures should receive PEP without delay.

One ID dose is 0.1 mL of vaccine and one IM dose is an entire vial of vaccine, irrespective of the vial size.

Should a vaccine dose be delayed for any reason, the PEP schedule should be resumed (not restarted).

Rabies Immunoglobulin(RIG): 

  • RIG provides a passive immunization and is administered only once, as soon as possible after the initiation of PEP and not beyond 7 days after the first dose of vaccine.
  • Vaccines should never be withheld regardless of the availability of RIG.
  • Max dose: hRIG - 20IU/kg , eRIG - 40IU/kg body weight.
  • WHO has recommended the use of Monoclonal Antibodies (mAb) as a “cocktail” containing at least two antibodies against RABV, as alternatives for RIGs in PEP.
  • All of the rabies immunoglobulin, or as much as anatomically possible (but avoiding possible compartment syndrome), should be administered into or around the wound site or sites. The remaining immunoglobulin, if any, should be injected intramuscularly at a site distant from the site of vaccine administration. Rabies immunoglobulin may be diluted to a volume sufficient for all wounds to be effectively and safely infiltrated.
  • Prioritization of RIG allocation: Multiple bites>Deep wounds>Bites to head, neck, and hands>Patients with severe immunodeficiency>The biting animal is confirmed or probable rabies>Bites, scratches, and exposure of mucous membranes caused by a bat.

(PrEP)Pre-exposure prophylaxis

  • PrEP considered in remote, rabies-endemic areas where access to PEP is difficult, the dog bite incidence is >5% per year or vampire bat rabies are known to be present.
  • Pre-exposure rabies vaccination consists of three intramuscular (IM) or intradermal (ID) doses are given on days 0, 7, and 21 or 28. For adults, the vaccine should always be administered in the deltoid area of the arm; for young children (under 1 year of age), the anterolateral area of the thigh is recommended. Rabies vaccine should never be administered in the gluteal area. Administration in this manner will result in lower neutralizing antibody titers.
  • For exposed or re-exposed patients who can document previous complete PrEP or PEP the following guidelines would be applicable:
    • Proper wound management should be done.
    • There is no need for the administration of RIG.
    • One site ID or IM vaccine administration on days 0 and 3.
    Only adequate wound washing would be required in case of re-exposure where the animal bite victim has documented proof of complete PEP or PrEP within the last three months.
    • People who have previously received full post-exposure treatment with neural tissue vaccines (NTV) or vaccine of unproven potency or cannot document complete PEP or PrEP treatment should be treated as a fresh case and given full PEP.

questions.text:
Given below are few logos of important national programs. Which of the following four options incorrectly matches the logo with the National program?
  1. Family planning program (FPP)
  2. National vector borne disease control program (NVBDCP)
  3. POSHAN Abhiyan / National Nutrition Mission( NNM)
  4. Prevention of Parent to child transmission of HIV/AIDS (PPTCT)
  5. National Program for control of Blindness and Visual Impairement (NPCB-VI)
  6. Integrated Child development scheme (ICDS)
  7. National Programme for Prevention and Control of Cancer, Diabetes, Cardiovascular Disease, and Stroke (NPCDCS)
questions.solution:
The correct answer is D-6.

The individual logos are explained as under: 

 

Figure - A:

The logo signifies Prevention of Parent to Child Transmission(PPTCT). The program was launched in 2002. Under this program, pregnant women are provided with counseling and testing in the Integrated Counselling and Testing Centre (ICTC). This program aims to prevent the perinatal transmission of HIV from an infected pregnant mother to her newborn baby.

Figure - B:

National Vector Borne Disease Control Programme (NVBDCP) is the nodal agency for the prevention of control of the following vector-borne diseases:

  • Kala-azar (also called visceral leishmaniasis)
  • Malaria
  • Dengue
  • Filariasis
  • Japanese encephalitis
  • Chikungunya.

Figure - C:

The given logo is of Integrated child development scheme under the Ministry of Woman and Child Development.

Figure - D:

The image shows the National Programme for Prevention and Control of Cancer, Diabetes, Cardiovascular Disease, and Stroke (NPCDCS).

Note: NAFLD has been integrated into NPCDCS in 2021. 

Figure - E:

National Programme for the Control of Blindness and Visual Impairment (NPCBVI). The levels of eye care, according to NPCBVI are:

  • Primary level: Sub-district level hospitals, community health centers, mobile ophthalmic units, upgraded PHCs, link workers, Panchayats.
  • Secondary level: District hospitals, NGO eye hospitals
  • Tertiary levels: Regional institutes of Ophthalmology, medical colleges.

The goal is to reduce the prevalence of blindness to 0.3% by 2020.

Figure - F:

POSHAN Abhiyaan /National Nutrition Mission( NNM) is a flagship program of the Ministry of Women and Child Development (MWCD), with a goal to achieve an improvement in the nutritional status of children from 0-6 years, adolescent girls, pregnant women, and lactating mothers during the next three years beginning 2017-18

Figure - G:

The given image is the new logo of the 360-degree holistic family planning campaign. The brand ambassador of this program is Amitabh Bachchan.

questions.text: Which of the following statement is false about the Ayushman Bharat-National Health Protection Mission?

choices.text: Government provides health insurance cover of up to Rs. 5,00,000 per family per year.
The limit of the size of the family that is covered is upto 7 members.
Hospitals cannot deny treatment to the diseases and the families covered under the scheme.
It covers secondary and tertiary care hospitalization.

questions.solution:
There is no cap on family size or the age of the members. All the families listed under the Socio-Economic Caste Census database are covered as per the defined criteria.

Ayushman Bharat-National Health Protection Mission: To build a comprehensive need-based health care service. 

Components: The target of the two initiatives mentioned below are to build a New India 2022.

  • Creation of 1,50,000 Health and Wellness Centres- These centers will provide Comprehensive Primary Health Care (CPHC), covering both maternal and child health services and non-communicable diseases, including free essential drugs and diagnostic services.
  • The second component is the National Health Protection Mission (NHPM) which provides health protection coverage to poor and vulnerable families. The Health and Wellness Centres will play a critical role in creating awareness about AB-NHPM, screening for non-communicable diseases, and follow-up of hospitalization cases among others.

Beneficiary Level: 

  • The government provides health insurance coverage of up to Rs. 5,00,000 per family per year.
  • All families listed in the SECC database as per the defined criteria will be covered. No cap on family size and age of members.
  • Priority to a girl child, women, and senior citizens.
  • Free treatment is available at all public and empaneled private hospitals in times of need.
  • Covers secondary and tertiary care hospitalization.
  • 1,350 medical packages covering surgery, medical and daycare treatments, cost of medicines, and diagnostics.
  • All pre-existing diseases are covered. Hospitals cannot deny treatment.
  • Cashless and paperless access to quality health care services.
  • Hospitals will not be allowed to charge any additional money from beneficiaries for the treatment.
  • Can reach out for information, assistance, complaints, and grievances to a 24X7 helpline number - 14555

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false about par boiling?

choices.text: Parboiling refers to partial cooking of rice in steam
The hot soaking process is used for par boiling.
Vitamins and minerals are driven into endosperm due to par boiling.
Par boiling softens the rice grains and makes it resistant to insects.

questions.solution:
Par boiling hardens the rice grains (not softens) and makes it resistant to insects.

Par boiling:

Par boiling is the process of partial cooking of rice in steam.

The hot soaking process is used for par boiling and it was developed by the Central Food Technological Research Institute (CFTRI), Mysore.

It preserves the nutritive quality of rice as during the process, vitamins and minerals in the outer aleurone layer are driven into inner endosperm.

The advantages are:

  • Preserves nutritive quality
  • Hardens the grains
  • Makes the rice grains insect resistant

questions.text: Which of the following gives the approximate magnitude of completed family size?
questions.solution:
Total fertility rate gives the approximate magnitude of completed family size.

Related Pearl: Fertility Indicators

  • Crude birth rate
    • It is the simplest measure of fertility although its usage is unsatisfactory.
    • It is the number of live births per 1000 estimated mid-year population in a given year.
    • Birth rate = No. of live births during the year x 1000/Estimated mid-year population
    • India, as per SRS bulletin 2018, had a birth rate of 20.0 per 1000 population
  • General Fertility Rate
    • It is the number of live births per 1000 women in the reproductive age group (15 - 49 years) in a given year.
    • GFR = Number of live births in an area in a year x 1000/Mid-year population of women in the reproductive age in the same area in the same year.
    • It is a better indicator of fertility than crude birth rate
    • The demerit of this indicator is that not all women in the denominator are exposed to childbirth
  • Age-specific fertility rates
    • It is the number of live births in a year to 1000 women in any specified age group.
    • It is a more precise measure of fertility and is also a sensitive indicator of family planning achievement.
    • ASFR = Number of live births in a particular age group x 1000/Mid-year female population of the same age group.
  • Total Fertility Rate
    • It represents the average number of children a woman would have if she were to pass through her reproductive years bearing children at the same rates as the women in each age group now.
    • It is the sum of all age specific fertility rates multiplied by 5.
    • This measure gives the approximate magnitude of completed family size.
  • Gross Reproductive Rate
    • It is the average number of girls that would be born to a woman if she experiences the current fertility pattern throughout her reproductive span, assuming no mortality.
  • Net Reproduction Rate
    • It is the number of daughters a newborn girl will bear during her lifetime assuming age-specific fertility and mortality rates.
    • NRR is a demographic indicator.
    • NRR of 1 is equivalent of approximately the 2 child norm.
    • If the NRR is less than 1, then the reproductive performance of the population is said to be inadequate.

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding the chlorination of water?

choices.text: Orthotolidine test measures only combined chlorine
Chlorine acts best when pH of water is around 7
It kills bacteria, viruses, spores and slime organisms
Hypochlorite ions are mainly responsible for the disinfectant activity

questions.solution:
Chlorine acts best when the pH of water is around 7 because of the predominance of the hypochlorous acid.

When the pH of the water exceeds 8.5, then 90 per cent of the hypochlorous acid gets converted to hypochlorite ions.  Most water sources have water that has a pH of around 6.5–7, making chlorination an effective form of disinfection.

Related Pearl: Chlorination of Water

  • Chlorination is widely used for large scale purification of water and for drinking water.
  • It is bactericidal and moderately virucidal but not sporicidal, except in high doses.
  • Alongside its anti-pathogenic attributes, it oxidizes iron, manganese and hydrogen sulphide. It also destroys some taste and odor producing components. It controls algae and slime organisms and aids in coagulation.
  • Action of chlorine:
    • Hydrochloric acid and hypochlorous acid are formed when chlorine is added to water. Hypochlorous acid ionizes to form hydrogen and hypochlorite ions.
    • H2O + Cl2 → HCl + HOCl
      HOCl → H + OCl
    • The disinfecting action of chlorine is predominantly due to hypochlorous acid. Hypochlorous acid is the most effective form of chlorine and it is almost 70 – 80 times more effective than hypochlorite ions.
    • Chlorine acts best in water that has a pH of around 7.
  • Principles of chlorination:
    • The water to be disinfected must be clear of turbidity as turbidity impedes efficient chlorination.
    • The chlorine demand of water is the difference between the amount of chlorine added to the water and the amount of residual chlorine remaining at the end of a specific period of contact (usually 60 minutes) at a given temperature and pH of the water. This has to be estimated before chlorination is done.
    • The point at which the chlorine demand of water is met is called the breakpoint. It is beyond this that residual free chlorine begins to appear.
    • Contact period of free chlorine for at least one hour is required to kill bacteria and viruses.
    • Minimum recommended concentration of free chlorine is 0.5 mg/litre for one hour. Free residual chlorine provides a margin of safety against microbial contamination that occurs in storage or transport.
    • The sum of the chlorine demand of the specific water plus free residual chlorine of 0.5 mg/litre constitutes the correct dose of chlorine to be applied.
  • Methods of chlorination
    • Chlorine gas: It is the first choice as it is cheap, quick and efficient in action and easy to apply. Special chlorinating equipments like Paterson’s chloronome are used for application of chlorine gas.
    • Chloramines: These loose compounds of chlorine and ammonia give more persistent forms of residual chlorine. They have slow action and thus are not widely used.
    • Perchloron or high test hypochlorite (H.T.H.): It is a calcium compound that has 60 – 70% of available chlorine.
  • Break point chlorination:
    • The point at which the chlorine demand of water is met is called the breakpoint.
    • Free chlorine (HOCl and OCl) appears when chlorine is added beyond the breakpoint.
    • In other words, at the breakpoint, if chlorine is added, then all the combined chlorines have been completely destroyed and free residual chlorines begin to appear.
    • This corresponding dosage to achieve appearance of free residual chlorine is called breakpoint dosage and this method is called breakpoint chlorination.
    • It is also called controlled superchlorination
    • Superchlorination followed by dechlorination is used to disinfect highly polluted waters whose quality fluctuates greatly.
  • Orthotolidine (OT) test:
    • It is a test for chlorination and determines free and combined chlorine in water, rapidly and accurately.
    • The reagent used is analytical grade Orthotolidine dissolved in 10% solution of hydrochloric acid.
    • When added to water which contains chlorine, it turns yellow with varying intensity. This is faster in the presence of free chlorine and slower in the presence of combined chlorines.
  • Orthotolidine - arsenite (OTA) test:
    • This is a modification of the OT test which nullifies the errors caused due to interfering substances like iron, nitrites, manganese, etc.
    • It determines free and combined chlorines separately.

questions.text: The insect shown below is a vector for a disease that is targetted under the National Vector Borne Disease Control Programme. Identify the disease.
questions.solution:
The image shown is of the Culex species of mosquitoes, which is a vector for Japanese Encephalitis and Bancroftian filariasis. 

Mansonia species is the vector for Malayan filariasis.

World mosquito day is celebrated annually on August 20 to create awareness about mosquito-borne diseases. It is a commemoration of a British doctor, Sir Ronald Ross’s discovery in 1897 that ‘female mosquitoes transmit malaria between humans’.

Related Pearl: The Mosquito

The mosquito as a vector:

  • Mosquitoes are global in distribution.
  • The main species of mosquitoes include the Anopheles, Culex, Aedes and Mansonia.
  • Flight range varies up to 11 kms, except Aedes for which it is 100 metres.
  • Life span of mosquitoes is around 8 to 34 days.
  • Their morphology consists of a head with a proboscis, a pair of palpi and a pair of antennae; a thorax and an abdomen.

Charateristics:

EggsUsually 100-250. This stage lasts 1 – 2 days. Laid singly; boat-shaped with lateral floats. Laid in clusters or rafts. Laid singly. Laid in star shaped clusters.
Larval stageThis stage lasts for 5 -7 days.

No siphon tube.

Lies parallel to undersurface of water.

Has siphon tube.

Lies in water with head faced downwards.

Has siphon tube.

Lies in water with head faced downwards.

Has siphon tube.

Lies in water with head faced downwards.
Adults Wings spotted. Wings unspotted. Wings unspotted. Stripped body. Wings unspotted.
Breeding areas Clean water Dirty and polluted water Artifical collections of water Water bodies containing aquatic vegetation
Diseases Malaria, filaria Bancroftian filariasis, Japanese encephalitis, West Nile fever, viral arthritis. Yellow fever, dengue, DHF, chikungunya, rift valley fever, filariasis,Zika virus Malayan filariasis
Comments Anopheline mosquitoes tend to sit with their heads low and their rear ends raised high, especially when feeding. 
  • Called "Nuisance mosquitoes"
  • These culicine female mosquitoes keep their bodies horizontal while feeding.

Called as tiger mosquitoes and they are day biters

They get the"tiger" name from white stripes  on its legs.

questions.text: A 42-year-old male who was asymptomatic was tested positive for COVID-19. Home-quarantine was recommended, and you were asked to provide instructions regarding the waste management to the patient and his family. You would instruct to discard all of the following in a yellow bag, except:

choices.text: Gloves used by the family in contact with patient

questions.solution:
Gloves used by the family in contact with the patient are considered as general waste, and should not be discarded in the yellow bag.

 

Central pollution control board (CPCB) has recommended the following measures for biomedical waste management in Home-quarantine for COVID-19:

  • The general solid waste, including kitchen waste, left-over foods, tetra packs, bottles used by the patient should be collected and securely tied in a bag to be handed over to the waste collector from local municipal bodies.
  • Used masks, gloves, tissues or swabs contaminated with blood or body fluids of COVID-19 patients, including used syringes, medicines, etc should be discarded in the yellow bag.
  • Masks and gloves used by persons other than COVID-19 patients (Option b) should be kept separate, in a paper bag for a minimum of 72-hrs. These masks and gloves are then cut or shredded to prevent re-use and disposed of as general solid waste.

Broken or discarded and contaminated glass including medicine vials and ampules except those containing cytotoxic waste.

Metallic Body implants

Sodium hypochlorite/Autoclaving/
Microwaving/Hydroclaving

Later - Recycling

 Note: Ash from incineration of biomedical waste shall be disposed of at common hazardous waste treatment and disposal facility. However, it may be disposed of in a municipal landfill, if the toxic metals in incineration ash are within the regulatory quantities as defined under the Hazardous Waste (Management and Handling and Transboundary Movement) Rules, 2008 as amended from time to time.

questions.text: In which stage of the demographic cycle does the demographic gap start increasing?
questions.solution:
The demographic gap starts increasing and attains maximum level during the early expanding phase.

Related Pearl: Demographic Process and Cycle

  • Demographic process
    • Fertility
    • Mortality
    • Marriage
    • Migration
    • Social Mobility
  • Demographic cycle
    • Stage 1 : High stationary 
      • High birth rate and high death rate render the population stationary.
      • Narrow demographic gap.
    • Stage 2 : Early expanding 
      • Death rate declines and birth rate remains unchanged
      • Demographic gap starts increasing and then becomes maximum
    • Stage 3 : Late expanding
      • Death rate decline further and birth rate falls
      • India is in this stage, currently
      • Demographic gap starts declining
    • Stage 4 : Low stationary 
      • Low birth rate and low death rate renders the population stationary
      • Narrow demographic gap
    • Stage 5 : Declining 
      • Population begins to decline as birth rate is lower than death rate
      • Demographic gap is negative

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false under the general norm with regard to ASHA?

choices.text: Few responsibilities are integrated with Anganwadi worker.
Has formal education up to class 10 at least
A population of 1000 should have at least 1 ASHA.
Has to procure ORS, contraceptives, IFA tablets from CHC

questions.solution:
An Accredited Social Health Activist (ASHA) does not procure ORS, contraceptives, IFA tablets, etc. from the CHC for her community.

An ASHA acts as a depot holder for these essential supplies, hence making it readily available to her community. These include Oral Rehydration Therapy (ORS), Iron Folic Acid Tablet (IFA), chloroquine, Disposable Delivery Kits (DDK), Oral Pills & Condoms, etc.

General norm:

  • Must be a woman - married/divorced/widow (age group 25-45 years)
  • Must be a resident of that village
  • Formal education of up to 10th standard
  • At least 1 ASHA for a population of 1000.

Relaxations in the general norm:

  • If no candidate is available with a qualification of 10th standard, the requirement can be relaxed to 8th standard.
  • In tribal, hilly and desert areas, the norm can be relaxed to 1 ASHA per habitation.

Note: The States have been given the flexibility to relax the population norms as well as the educational qualifications on a case to case basis, depending on the local conditions as far as her recruitment is concerned. However, these are exceptions and not the general norm.

Related Pearl: ASHA

ASHA is an Accredited Social Health Activist.

An ASHA must be a woman, a resident of the village, 25 to 45 years old and have a formal education till 10th standard preferably if they are in good numbers. This may be relaxed upto 8th standard only if no suitable person with this qualification is available. She is part of the primary health care at the village level.

National norm: In rural areas, a population of 1000 should have at least 1 ASHA, but in remote areas, one ASHA per habitation is the norm. In urban areas, 1 ASHA worker is assigned to a population of 1000-2500. This norm is also mandated by each state, differently, according to their requirements. 

Responsibilities of ASHA:

    • Health education and awareness
    • Reproductive and child health and family planning
    • Facilitate the access to health services
    • Promotion of sanitation and household toilet construction
    • Provision of primary medical care for minor ailments
    • Provider of DOTS
    • Depot holder of essentials like ORS, iron and folic acid tablets, condoms, disposable delivery kits, etc.
    • Dispersal of health information on her community to higher centres
    • Some responsibilities are integrated with Anganwadi workers and Auxiliary Nurse Midwife

questions.text: According to the Employees State Insurance Act, a woman in the reproductive age group undergoing a tubectomy procedure would receive the cash benefit under ____.
questions.solution:
Insured persons in the productive age group undergoing sterilization procedures such as tubectomy and vasectomy are offered cash benefit under the ESI Act as Enhanced sickness benefit. The Enhanced Sickness Benefit equal to full wage is payable to insured persons undergoing sterilization for 7 days for male and 14 days for female workers.

 

 

Related Pearl: ESI ACT, 1948

Employees State Insurance Act, 1948 (Revised)

Scope: It is applicable to all factories in India excluding

  • Defense 
  • Railway  
  • Mines 

Finance Contribution

  • Employee – 0.75% of his daily wage 
  • Employer – 3.25% of the employees' daily wage
  • Medical benefit – 1/8th by the state government and 7/8th by the ESI Corporation.

Benefits

To the Employees

  • Medical Benefit- no cash benefit, full medical care is provided.
  • Sickness Benefit- is given at 70% of daily wage for a duration of 91 days in one year 
    • Extended sickness benefit – 80% of the daily wages for a duration of 2 years for 34 specified diseases 
    • Enhanced sickness benefit – at full wages for sterilization procedure for a duration of 7 days post-vasectomy and 14 days post tubectomy. 
  • Maternity Benefit – Benefit is payable at full wages for 26 weeks (6.5 months) for pregnancy, 6 weeks following a miscarriage, and 30 days for sickness arising out of pregnancy
  • Dependance Benefit– is at 90% daily wages, lifelong for the spouse and parents and till the age of 18 years for any dependant's child, however, the benefit is withdrawn if the daughter is married earlier.
  • Disablement Benefits – temporary disability – is as long as the person is disabled at 90% daily wages. Permanent disability – the lifetime pension 
  • Funeral Benefit – Rs.15,000/-
  • Rehabilitation Benefit- on payment of Rs. 10, the insured person and his/her family continue to get medical treatment after permanent disablement or retirement.

To the Employers

  • Exemption from workman compensation act 
  • Exemption from maternity benefit act 
  • Income tax rebate on the amount contributed towards the scheme.

Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine 25th edition (Page no: 877)

https://www.esic.nic.in/information-benefits.

questions.text: The school health programs are managed by which of the following?
questions.solution:
The school health programs are managed by the primary health centre (PHC).

The School Health Committee (1961) in India recommended that the school health services should be a part of the general health services. Since the general health services are administered through PHCs, school health programs are also managed by the PHCs under their jurisdiction.

The School Health Committee advocated the formation of school health committees at the village level, block level, district level, state level, and national level. The National School Health Council will be an advisory and coordinating body.

PHCs provide the following school health services:

  • Screening of general health assessment of anemia/nutritional status, visual acuity, hearing problem, dental check-up, physical disabilities, learning disorders, and behavior problems, etc.
  • Basic medicines for common ailments
  • Immunization 
  • Micronutrient (Vitamin A, iron, and folic acid) management
  • Deworming 
  • Mid-day meal

 Note: National Programme for Mid-Day Meal in Schools has recently been renamed Pradhan Mantri Poshan Shakti Nirman (PM POSHAN).  

Related Pearl: Primary Health Centres-PHC

  • One PHC per 30,000 population in plain areas and 20,000 in remote areas with a minimum of 6 beds.
  • Types:
    • Type A: PHC with less than 20 deliveries per month.
    • Type B: PHC with 20 or more deliveries per month.
  • Functions:
    • Medical care: OPD, emergencies, referrals and in-patient services.
    • Maternal and child health care, family planning and MTP
    • Health education
    • Nutrition services: malnutrition, vitamin A deficiency, anemia.
    • School and adolescent health services
    • Prevention and control of locally endemic diseases
    • Recording, collection, and reporting of vital events
    • Promotion of sanitation and testing of water
    • National health programme functions
    • Referral services
    • Training of health workers, ASHAs, ANMs, etc.
    • Basic laboratory services
    • Monitoring and supervising activities
    • Selected surgical procedures
    • Mainstreaming AYUSH and PMR

questions.text: Urban HEART programme is __?

choices.text: Urban Health Equity Assessment and Response Tool
Urban Health Evaluation Assessment and Response Tool
Urban Health Equity Assessment and Response Technique
Urban Health Evaluation Assessment and Response Technique

questions.solution:
Urban HEART stands for Urban Health Equity Assessment and Response Tool and facilitates the process of addressing health inequities across the world.

Urban HEART guides local policymakers and communities through a standardized procedure of gathering relevant evidence and planning efficiently for appropriate actions to tackle health inequities.

Three main approaches applied to measure and tackle inequities in health are:

  • targeting disadvantaged population groups or social classes
  • narrowing the health gap
  • reducing inequities throughout the whole population.     

Core elements of Urban HEART:

  • sound evidence
  • intersectoral action for health
  • community participation

Urban HEART is expected to achieve the following:

  • local and national authorities equipped with relevant evidence to inform important decisions related to prioritization and resource allocation
  • communities mobilized and empowered to promote health equity
  • multiple sectors engaged in addressing common goals, including the promotion of health equity
  • people living in cities with better health and social status, and reduced inequities in health between population groups.

questions.text: The "No Smoking " sign is an example of _______ approach towards health education.
questions.solution:
The No Smoking sign is an example of regulatory approach.

A regulatory approach with respect to health education is defined as a government intervention, direct or indirect, designed to alter human behaviour.

Regulations may take many forms, from prohibition to imprisonment. Examples of this approach include The Child Marriage Restraint Act and the use of compulsory seatbelts. However, there are many failures to this approach, as some of these approaches involve personal choices like diet, exercise, smoking, etc

The Four approaches to health education:

  • Regulatory approach
  • Service approach
  • Health education approach
  • Primary health care approach
Regulatory approach Service approach  Health Education approach Primary health care approach
Government intervention to alter human behavior laws Facilities are provided by the government for use Awareness-> interest->Evaluation The health of the people, for the people, by the people where principles of community participation and intersectoral coordination are stressed
Ex: Child marriage Act, No smoking in public places; Helmet law Ex: Government provided latrines free of cost yet people did not use them because its need was not felt Ex: Adoption of ORS for diarrhea

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about ice-lined refrigerators (ILR)?

choices.text: Smaller ILRs are given to PHCs and the larger ones to district vaccine stores
They have temperature zones for different vaccines
Kata thermometer is used to record temperature inside the ILR
Most ILRs are provided with baskets to store vaccines

questions.solution:
Dial or digital thermometers are used to record temperatures inside an ice-lined refrigerator.

  • ILRs are the main method of vaccine storage in primary health centers. They are an important part of the cold chain and they maintain a temperature of 2 to 8 °C for the storage of vaccines.

    They have different temperature zones for different vaccines. The upper zone is for freeze-sensitive vaccines like Cholera, Hep B, Rotavirus(liquid), etc. All vaccines are kept in the basket provided with ILR. vaccines like OPV, BCG, measles, and JE can be kept at the bottom of the basket while, DPT, TT, Hep B, IPV, and pentavalent vaccines and diluents are kept in the upper part of the basket.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man with a history of small streaks of blood in stools without any other complaints is being sent for a colonoscopy for early diagnosis of colon cancer. This type of prevention is _______
questions.solution:
Colonoscopies for early detection of colon cancer is an example of secondary prevention.

Early diagnosis (including screening) and treatment is the component of secondary prevention. Some of the examples of secondary prevention are as follows:

  • Papanicolaou (Pap) smear for early detection of cervical cancer
  • Mammography, for early detection of breast cancer
  • Colonoscopies, for early detection of colon cancer
  • Blood Pressure Screening

Secondary prevention measures focus on the sub-clinical stage and the early clinical stage, such as dysplasia in this case. These measures enable early detection and prompt effective intervention to correct departures from a state of health.
